1.1 Notation and Delta Function

For a volume charge density œÅ, the electric field at r is given by

E(r)=4œÄœµo‚Äã1‚Äã‚à´‘â2‘â^‚ÄãœÅ(r‚Ä≤)dœÑ‚Ä≤

where ‘â=r‚àír‚Ä≤ and r‚Ä≤ is the location of a charge.

  1. For a point charge Q at the origin, œÅ(r)=QŒ¥(x)Œ¥(y)Œ¥(z). Evaluate the above integral using cartesian coordinates and unit vectors and this œÅ.

  2. For a point charge Q at r‚Ä≤, œÅ(r)=QŒ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)Œ¥(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)Œ¥(z‚àíz‚Ä≤). Evaluate the above integral using cartesian coordinates and unit vectors and this œÅ.

Solution

1.

E(r)=====‚Äã4œÄœµo‚Äã1‚Äã‚à´‚à´(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚ÄãQŒ¥(x‚Ä≤)Œ¥(y‚Ä≤)dx‚Ä≤dy‚Ä≤4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã‚à´Œ¥(y‚Ä≤)dy‚Ä≤‚à´(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚Ä≤)dx‚Ä≤4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã‚à´Œ¥(y‚Ä≤)dy‚Ä≤(x‚àí0)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àí0)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚Äã4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã(x‚àí0)2+(y‚àí0)2‚Äã3(x‚àí0)x^+(y‚àí0)y^‚Äã‚Äã4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äãx2+y2‚Äã3xx^+yy^‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

The generalization to the 3-D problem given is straightforward.

2. Here x‚Ä≤,y‚Ä≤, and z‚Ä≤ are fixed points in space. Normally when given a charge density, we replace x,y,z with x‚Ä≤,y‚Ä≤,z‚Ä≤. If we did that here, we would have œÅ(r‚Ä≤)=QŒ¥(0)Œ¥(0)Œ¥(0), which does not depend on primed coordinates. To work around this issue, change the integration variables to be double primes. As before, in two dimensions,

E(r)==‚Äã4œÄœµo‚Äã1‚Äã‚à´‚à´(x‚àíx‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚ÄãQŒ¥(x‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚àíx‚Ä≤)Œ¥(y‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚àíy‚Ä≤)dx‚Ä≤‚Ä≤dy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã‚à´Œ¥(y‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚àíy‚Ä≤)dy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚à´(x‚àíx‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚àíx‚Ä≤)dx‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Äã

In the integral above, the x‚Ä≤ is a constant with respect to integration (in the same way that in ‚à´Œ¥(x‚àía)dx, a is a constant) and so we replace x‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ with this constant value.

E(r)==‚Äã4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã‚à´Œ¥(y‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚àíy‚Ä≤)dy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚Äã4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

In class, I used an alternative approach where I replaced x‚Ä≤,y‚Ä≤,z‚Ä≤ with ax‚Äã,ay‚Äã,az‚Äã and integrated over x‚Ä≤,y‚Ä≤,z‚Ä≤ so that I needed to evaluate

E(r)=‚Äã4œÄœµo‚Äã1‚Äã‚à´‚à´(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2‚Äã3(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)x^+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)y^‚Äã‚ÄãQŒ¥(x‚Ä≤‚àíax‚Äã)Œ¥(y‚Ä≤‚àíay‚Äã)dx‚Ä≤dy‚Ä≤‚Äã

The result of integration is

E(r)=4œÄœµo‚ÄãQ‚Äã(x‚àíax‚Äã)2+(y‚àíay‚Äã)2‚Äã3(x‚àíax‚Äã)x^+(y‚àíay‚Äã)y^‚Äã‚Äã

To finish the problem, I replaced ax‚Äã,ay‚Äã,az‚Äã with the variables given in the problem of x‚Ä≤,y‚Ä≤,z‚Ä≤ to get the same answer as when integration was done over double primed variables.

1.2 Delta Function I

  1. Suppose I=‚à´‚àí22‚Äãg(x)dx. Find ‚à´‚àí11‚Äãg(2x)dx and ‚à´‚àí11‚Äãg(‚àí2x)dx in terms of I. Show graphically why the result makes sense using g(x)=x2.

  2. Show that ‚à´Œ¥(bx)f(x)dx=‚à£b‚à£f(0)‚Äã. (That is, show that Œ¥(bx)=Œ¥(x)/‚à£b‚à£).

Solution

1.

‚à´‚àí11‚Äãg(2x)dx=‚à´‚àí11‚Äãg(‚àí2x)dx=I/2

2. The generalization of the previous result is if I=‚à´‚àíab‚Äãg(x)dx, then for Œ±>0

‚à´‚àía/Œ±b/Œ±‚Äãg(Œ±x)dx=‚à´‚àía/Œ±b/Œ±‚Äãg(‚àíŒ±x)dx=Œ±I‚Äã.

In the case that a=b=‚àû and a finite integral, it follows that ‚à´g(bx)dx=‚à´‚à£b‚à£g(x)‚Äãdx, which applies to g(x)=Œ¥(x) and thus whe have shown Œ¥(bx)=Œ¥(x)/‚à£b‚à£.

Griffiths 4th Edition example 1.15 gives an alternative solution. Another approach is to think of this as a transformation of variables problem in which the Jacobian, which involves the absolute value, is computed.

1.3 Delta Function II

  1. Find ‚à´Œ¥(a+bx)f(x)dx using either

    1. identity 5. on page 26 of Jackson, 3rd Edition or

    2. using the substition u=a+bx.

  2. Prove identity 5. on Page 26 of Jackson 3rd edition

    Œ¥(f(x))=i‚àë‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãdxdf‚Äã(xi‚Äã)‚à£‚à£‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚àíxi‚Äã)‚Äã

    where f(x) is assumed to have only simple zeros, located at x=xi‚Äã. Do this by either

    1. explaing the omitted explanations in Dennery and Krzywicki 1967, page 237 or

    2. Taylor series expanding f(x) around the points xi‚Äã where g(xi‚Äã)=0.

Solution

1.1 To avoid confusion with the f(x) in the given equation, re-write the identity as

Œ¥(g(x))=i‚àë‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãdxdg‚Äã(xi‚Äã)‚à£‚à£‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚àíxi‚Äã)‚Äã

Here g(x)=a+bx, which has a single zero at x1‚Äã=‚àía/b. dg/dx=b, so

Œ¥(g(x))=‚à£dxdg‚Äã(x1‚Äã)‚à£Œ¥(x‚àíx1‚Äã)‚Äã=‚à£b‚à£Œ¥(x‚àíx1‚Äã)‚Äã=‚à£b‚à£Œ¥(x+a/b)‚Äã

and so

‚à´Œ¥(a+bx)f(x)dx=‚à´dx‚à£b‚à£Œ¥(x+a/b)‚Äãf(x)=‚à£b‚à£f(‚àía/b)‚Äã

1.2 With the substitution,

‚à´Œ¥(u)bf((u‚àíb)/a)‚Äãdu=bf(‚àíb/a)‚Äã

for positive b and f(‚àíb/a)/(‚àíb) for negative b, so the integral is f(‚àíb/a)/‚à£b‚à£ as before.

1.4 Divergence Theorem

  1. Find the electric field E due to a non-conducting sphere with a uniform volume charge density œÅo‚Äã and radius b that is centered on the origin.

  2. Show by direct calculation that

    ‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖda=‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

    when the volume of integration V is a sphere centered on the origin with

    1. radius b/2

    2. radius 2b

Solution

As mentioned in class, this is somewhat of a simple problem but was given to motivate the use of the Dirac delta function. What I said in class is briefly summarized at the end.

1. The electric field is

E(r‚â§b)=3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãrr^=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äãb3r‚Äãr^

E(r‚â•b)=3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãr2b3‚Äãr^=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äãr21‚Äãr^

where q=œÅo‚Äã4œÄb3/3 was used.

2. In the following,

A.‚àá‚ãÖ(f(r)r^)=r21‚Äã‚àÇr‚àÇ‚Äã(r2f(r))

is used. This follows from the identity for the divergence in spherical coordinates.

For r‚â§b and S a spherical surface of radius r:

‚àÆS‚ÄãE(r‚â§b)‚ãÖn^da=‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0œÄ‚Äã(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãrr^)‚ãÖr^r2sinŒ∏dŒ∏dœï=œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äã34œÄr3‚Äã=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

The divergence of E is, using A.,

‚àá‚ãÖE(r‚â§b)=‚àá‚ãÖ(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãrr^)=r21‚Äã‚àÇr‚àÇ‚Äã(r2(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãr))=œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äã

as expected from Gauss‚Äô law in differential form (‚àá‚ãÖE=œÅ/œµo‚Äã with œÅ=œÅo‚Äã). Therefore, for r‚â§b:

‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´V‚Äãœµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãd3x=œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äã34œÄr3‚Äã=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

Conclusion: for r‚â§b,

‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da=‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

For r>b and S a spherical surface of radius r:

‚àÆS‚ÄãE(r‚â•b)‚ãÖn^da=‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0œÄ‚Äã(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãr2b3‚Äãr^)‚ãÖr^r2sinŒ∏dŒ∏dœï=‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0œÄ‚Äã(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãb3)sinŒ∏dŒ∏dœï=œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äã34œÄb3‚Äã=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

The divergence is

‚àá‚ãÖE(r‚â•b)=3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äãb3‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äã=r21‚Äã‚àÇr‚àÇ‚Äã(r2(3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äãb3‚Äãr21‚Äã))=3œµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äãb3‚Äãr21‚Äã‚àÇr‚àÇ‚Äã(1)=0

also as expected from Gauss‚Äô law in differential form (‚àá‚ãÖE=œÅ/œµo‚Äã with œÅ=0). Important: the last equality in the above equation is only true when rÓÄ†=0; when r=0, the result is 0/0. This issue is considered later in this solution.

One must split the volume integral into two integrals, one for r‚â§b and the other for r>b to account for the divergence being different in the two regions. As shown earlier, in the region r>b, the divergence is zero.

‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x‚Äã====‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖE(r‚â§b)d3x‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãœµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äãd3xœµo‚ÄãœÅo‚Äã‚Äã34œÄb3‚Äãœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚Äã+++‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â•b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖE(r‚â•b)d3x‚à´Vr‚â•b‚Äã‚Äã0d3x0‚Äã

Conclusion: for r>b,

‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da=‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

Motivation for this problem

I gave this problem as a lead-in/follow-up for my discussion of the motivation for the delta function. For a point charge, the integrand of

‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x

with

Ep‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äãr2r^‚Äã

is zero everywhere except at the origin (r=0) where it is indeterminate in the form of 0/0 because

‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äãr21‚Äã‚àÇr‚àÇ‚Äã(1)={0/00‚Äãif r=0if rÓÄ†=0‚Äã

However,

‚àÆS‚ÄãEp‚Äã‚ãÖn^da=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

does not have an indeterminacy. Therefore, the divergence theorem

‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x=‚àÆS‚ÄãEp‚Äã‚ãÖn^da

applied to E for a point charge gives

indeterminate integral=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

In this problem, it has been shown that if a point charge q is modeled as having a uniform density for r‚â§b and having zero density for r>b, then the indeterminacy problem can be avoided and

‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da

for all r and for arbitrarily small (but non-zero) b (but see also ‚Äòother notes‚Äô below). That is, the divergence theorem gives the correct answer for a solid ball of charge that is arbitrarily small but not zero.

Although the divergence theorem does not apply for Ep‚Äã, to avoid having to think about a solid ball with arbitrarily small but non zero radius is to use it with the convention that

‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äã=œµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¥(r)

where the function Œ¥(r) is zero everywhere except at r=0 and integrates to 1 when the volume of integration includes r=0.

‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´V‚Äã4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äãd3x=‚à´V‚Äãœµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¥(r)d3x=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

That is,

‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äã=4œÄŒ¥(r)

When you see the delta function used in an integration, you should think back to this problem and realize that the delta function is being used instead of modeling the electric field as a point charge q as having a uniform density for r<b and zero density for r>b.

Griffiths takes a different approach to motivating the introduction of the delta function. He notes that the indeterminate integral of the divergence

‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x=indeterminate integral

must be equal to q/œµo‚Äã because of the divergence theorem (which technically does not apply because of the singularity in E at r=0):

‚àÆS‚ÄãEp‚Äã‚ãÖn^da=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚áí‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x=œµo‚Äãq‚Äã

He then notes that r^/r2 has the property that its divergence ‚àá‚ãÖr2r^‚Äã

  1. is zero everywhere except at the origin (where it is interminate)

  2. integrates to a constant (4œÄ) over any volume V that includes r=0 (based on the assumption that the divergence theorem applies and resolves the indeterminacy)

That is, although

‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x

has an indeterminate integrand at r=0, the divergence theorem must be true, and so this integral must be equal to the surface integral, which is œµo‚Äãq‚Äã. Therefore,

‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äã=œµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¥(r)

where the function Œ¥(r) is defined to be zero unless r=0 and integrates over a volume that includes r=0 to 1. This explanation is somewhat awkward because it asserts that the divergence theorem must be correct even though the field Ep‚Äã does not satisfy the requirements for the divergence theorem to apply. (The requirements for the divergence theorem to apply are that the components of the vector field and their derivatives are continuous.)

In summary, the integral

‚à´V‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

is indeterminant when E‚àºr^/r2 and V includes r=0. If we model a point charge as having a uniform density for r‚â§b, and zero density for r>b, where bÓÄ†=0 is smaller than any length scale in the problem, the indeterminacy is removed. Instead of two integrations, one for r‚â§b and the other for r>b, we can simply replace ‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äã with (q/œµo‚Äã)Œ¥(r); the result of any integration will be the same.

A second motivation for using the delta function is that we often want to do an integral of the form

‚à´V‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEp‚Äãd3x

(Recall that f(r) means f(x,y,z)). As before, integral is indeterminate because ‚àá‚ãÖ(r^/r2) is 0/0 at r=0. To work around this problem, we can again model the point charge as having a uniform density for r‚â§b and zero density for r>b. Then

‚à´V‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEb‚Äãd3x+‚à´Vr>b‚Äã‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEb‚Äãd3x

The second integral is identically zero because ‚àá‚ãÖEb‚Äã=0 for r>b. If f(r) can be expanded as a Taylor series

f(r)‚âÉf(0)+r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã;+;‚Ä¶

then

‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x‚Äã====‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã(f(0)+r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã+‚Ä¶)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãf(0)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x+‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã(r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã+‚Ä¶)‚àá‚ãÖEd3xf(0)‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x+‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã(r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã+‚Ä¶)‚àá‚ãÖEd3xœµo‚Äãq‚Äãf(0)+œµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã(r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã+‚Ä¶)d3x‚Äã

The second and higher-order terms in the last equation approach zero as b‚Üí0. To see this, note that for small enough b,

œµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãf(r)d3x‚Üí34œÄ‚Äãb3‚ü®f(0)‚ü©

where the ‚ü®‚ü© is the average in V in a sphere of radius b. Therefore,

œµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äãr‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äãd3xb‚Üí0‚Äãœµo‚Äãq‚Äã34œÄ‚Äãb3‚ü®r‚ãÖ[‚àáf]r=0‚Äã‚ü©b‚Üí0‚Äã0

The same argument applies to the higher-order terms in the Taylor series expansion.

Prior to the introduction of the delta function by Dirac in the 1930s, the above argument was used when an integral of the form

‚à´V‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

was encountered and E was that for a point charge and V that included the location of the point charge.

With the introduction of the Dirac delta, one can simply use ‚àá‚ãÖE=œµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¥(r) to get the same result without needing to think about the above steps:

‚à´V‚Äãf(r)‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´V‚Äãf(r)œµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¥(r)d3x={f(0)œµo‚Äãq‚Äã0‚Äãif V includes r=0otherwise‚Äã

That is, using the delta function for the divergence of E due to a point charge will give us the same answer as if we had modeled the point charge as having a uniform density for r‚â§b, zero density for r>b, Taylor series expanded f(r), and then let b‚Üí0.

Other notes

In the above, I showed that the divergence theorem gave the correct result for E and any r by direct calculation. However, the divergence theorem

‚àÆS‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da=‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

requires that within V, the components of E and their derivatives are continuous. In E, Er‚Äã is continuous, but ‚àÇEr‚Äã/‚àÇr is not. So it appears that direct calculation for r>b gave a result that was consistent with the divergence theorem even though the assumptions required to apply the divergence theorem are not satisfied. To see why this occurred, use the divergence theorem in the two parts of V where the divergence theorem applies for E.

First, consider the application of the divergence theorem for the volume between r=0 and r=b.

‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´Sr=b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da

The outward normal to Sr=b‚Äã for Vr‚â§b‚Äã is +r^, so

I.‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´Sr=b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖr^da

Next, consider the application of the divergence theorem for the volume between r=b and r=2b (the result will apply to any r>b). In this case, there is an inner and outer surface and so the surface integral has two parts.

‚à´Vb‚â§r‚â§2b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚àÆSr=b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da+‚àÆSr=2b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da

The outward normal to Sr=b‚Äã for this volume is ‚àír^ and the outward normal to Sr=2b‚Äã is +r^, so

II.‚à´Vb‚â§r‚â§2b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚àí‚àÆSr=b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖr^da+‚àÆSr=2b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖr^da

Using I. and II. with the volume integral expressed in two parts

‚à´Vr‚â§2b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´Vr‚â§b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x+‚à´Vb‚â§r‚â§2b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x

gives

‚à´Vr‚â§2b‚Äã‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖEd3x=‚à´Sr=2b‚Äã‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^da

(The surface integrals at r=b cancel because their normal directions are in opposite directions.)

2.1 Representing œÅ Using Œ¥ and Œò

The step (or Heavyside step) function, Œò, is defined by

Œò(x)={10‚Äãx>0x‚â§0‚Äã

Œò can be used to to express a charge density in a compact mathematical form. For example, instead of stating ‚Äúa uniformly charged sphere centered on the origin, with total charge Q, and radius b‚Äù, we can write œÅ(x,y,z)=(4/3)œÄb3Q‚ÄãŒò(b‚àír). When this density is integrated over all space, the result is Q:

‚à´œÅ(x)d3x=(4/3)œÄb3Q‚Äã‚à´02œÄ‚Äãdœï‚à´0œÄ‚ÄãsinŒ∏dŒ∏‚à´0‚àû‚ÄãŒò(b‚àír)r2dr

Because Œò(b‚àír)=0 for r‚â•b and Œò(b‚àír)=1 for r<b, the limits on the r integral can be modfied and the Œò function removed:

‚à´œÅ(x)d3x=(4/3)œÄb3Q‚Äã‚à´02œÄ‚Äãdœï‚à´0œÄ‚ÄãsinŒ∏dŒ∏‚à´0b‚Äãr2dr

The integrals above evaluate to the volume of a sphere of radius b so that

‚à´œÅ(x)d3x=Q

  1. Write the piecewise function f(x)={10‚Äã‚à£x‚à£<b‚à£x‚à£‚â•b‚Äã using one or more Œò functions.

  2. Find the volume charge density œÅ in cylindrical coordinates in terms of Œ¥ and/or Œò for an infinitely long cylinder of radius b with a charge density per unit length of Œªo‚Äã uniformly distributed on its surface. Assume that the cylinder‚Äôs centerline is along the z-axis.

  3. Repeat 2. assuming the cylinder is finite and extends from z=‚àíh/2 to z=h/2.

Solution

  1. As mentioned in class, an easy way to solve this is to write f(x) as the sum of two step functions. One shifted to the left by b, corresponding to Œò(x+b); the other shifted to the right and inverted, corresponding to Œò(x‚àíb). Thus,

    f(x)=Œò(x+b)‚àíŒò(x‚àíb).

    Other solutions:

    f(x)=Œò(b‚àí‚à£x‚à£)

    f(x)=Œò(b2‚àíx2)=Œò[(b‚àíx)(b+x)]

    f(x)=Œò(b+x)‚àíŒò(x‚àíb)

    It may be interesting to use dŒò/dx=Œ¥(x) develop an identity for Œò(f(x)) similar to identity 5. on page 26 of Jackson 4th Edition.

    Checks:

    • when x=0, f(x)=Œò(b)‚àíŒò(‚àíb)=1‚àí0=1

    • when x=2b, f(x)=Œò(3b)‚àíŒò(b)=1‚àí1=0

    • when x=‚àí2b, f(x)=Œò(‚àíb)‚àíŒò(‚àí3b)=0‚àí0=0

  2. We want a charge distribution that is localized at a cylindrical radial distance b. œÅ(s)=CŒ¥(s‚àíb) has this feature, where C is a constant. We also need the integral of this charge density over all space to equal the total charge on the cylinder, which is Q=Œªo‚Äãh assuming that the length of the cylinder is h. Thus, we need to find C such that

    Q=Œªo‚Äãh=‚à´œÅ(x)d3x

    Q=Œªo‚Äãh=‚à´‚àíh/2h/2‚Äã‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0‚àû‚ÄãCŒ¥(s‚àíb)sdsdœïdz

    Q=Œªo‚Äãh=2œÄhC‚à´0‚àû‚ÄãŒ¥(s‚àíb)sds=2œÄhCb‚áíC=Œªo‚Äã/2œÄb

    and so

    œÅ(x)=2œÄbŒªo‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥(s‚àíb)

    Equivalently, we can write

    œÅ(x)=2œÄsŒªo‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥(s‚àíb)

    because Œ¥(s‚àíb)/s=Œ¥(s‚àíb)/b, which follows from the fact that the delta function is only non-zero at s=b.

  3. Here we apply the result from part 1. with the replacement of b in that problem with h/2:

    œÅ(x)=2œÄbŒªo‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥(s‚àíb)[Œò(x+h/2)‚àíŒò(x‚àíh/2)]

2.2 Green‚Äôs Reciprocity Theorem

For discrete charges, Green‚Äôs Reciprocity Theorem for N charges is

i=1‚àëN‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Äãqi‚Ä≤‚Äã=i=1‚àëN‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã

Consider charges q1‚Äã,q2‚Äã, and q3‚Äã at locations x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã, and x3‚Äã, respectively, on the x-axis. At these locations, the potentials are Œ¶1‚Äã,Œ¶2‚Äã, and Œ¶3‚Äã, respectively.

If a new system of charges q1‚Ä≤‚Äã,q2‚Ä≤‚Äã, and q3‚Ä≤‚Äã is created by placing them at the same locations x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã, and x3‚Äã, respectively, the potentials at these locations are Œ¶1‚Ä≤‚Äã,Œ¶2‚Ä≤‚Äã, and Œ¶3‚Ä≤‚Äã, respectively.

Show that

i=1‚àë3‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Äãqi‚Ä≤‚Äã=i=1‚àë3‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã

Solution

The physical interpretation of Green‚Äôs Reciprocity theorem is that the work required to put charges an unprimed set of charges at x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,x3‚Äã under the influence of only the electric field of a primed set of charges x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,x3‚Äã must be the same as the work required to put a primed set of charges at x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,x3‚Äã under the influence of only the electric field of an unprimed set of charges at x1‚Äã,x2‚Äã,x3‚Äã.

Using

Œ¶i‚Äã=j=1jÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àëN‚Äã‚à£xj‚Äã‚àíxi‚Äã‚à£qj‚Äã‚Äã=j=1jÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdji‚Äãqj‚Äã‚Äã

gives, for N=3, the left-hand side terms in ‚àëi=13‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Äãqi‚Ä≤‚Äã=‚àëi=13‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã

Œ¶1‚Äãq1‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶2‚Äãq2‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶3‚Äãq3‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã===‚Äã0d12‚Äãq1‚Äãq2‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äãd13‚Äãq1‚Äãq3‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã+++‚Äãd21‚Äãq2‚Äãq1‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã0d23‚Äãq2‚Äãq3‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã+++‚Äãd31‚Äãq3‚Äãq1‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äãd32‚Äãq3‚Äãq2‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã0‚Äã‚Äã

The right-hand side terms in ‚àëi=13‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Äãqi‚Ä≤‚Äã=‚àëi=13‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã can be expanded as

Œ¶1‚Ä≤‚Äãq1‚ÄãŒ¶2‚Ä≤‚Äãq2‚ÄãŒ¶3‚Ä≤‚Äãq3‚Äã‚Äã===‚Äã0d12‚Äãq1‚Ä≤‚Äãq2‚Äã‚Äãd13‚Äãq1‚Ä≤‚Äãq3‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã+++‚Äãd21‚Äãq2‚Ä≤‚Äãq1‚Äã‚Äã0d23‚Äãq2‚Ä≤‚Äãq3‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã+++‚Äãd31‚Äãq3‚Ä≤‚Äãq1‚Äã‚Äãd32‚Äãq2‚Äãq3‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã0‚Äã‚Äã

In the above, the left‚Äì and right‚Äìhand sides of the equation to prove were written in the form of a matrix. In this form, one can see that the matrices are transposes of each other. If we sum all elements in a matrix, the result is the same if we sum all elements of that matrix transposed.

More generally, one can use

i=1‚àëN‚Äãqi‚ÄãŒ¶i‚Ä≤‚Äã=i=1‚àëN‚Äãqi‚Äãj=1jÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdij‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äã‚Äã=i=1‚àëN‚Äãj=1jÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdij‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã‚Äã

Repeating with the primed and unprimed swapped and starting with a dummy index of j instead of i, we have

j=1‚àëN‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶j‚Äã=j=1‚àëN‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äãi=1iÓÄ†=j‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdji‚Äãqi‚Äã‚Äã=j=1‚àëN‚Äãi=1iÓÄ†=j‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdij‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã‚Äã

Where in the last step, dji‚Äã=dij‚Äã was used.

One can think of qj‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã/dij‚Äã as elements in a matrix. The equations

i=1‚àëN‚Äãj=1jÓÄ†=i‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdij‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã‚Äã and j=1‚àëN‚Äãi=1iÓÄ†=j‚Äã‚àëN‚Äãdij‚Äãqj‚Ä≤‚Äãqi‚Äã‚Äã

both result in the sum of all elements of a matrix excluding the diagonals. The only difference is the order in which the elements of the matrix are summed. For a continuous charge distribution, we would use the fact that the order of integration could be changed to arrive at the result ‚à´dqŒ¶‚Ä≤(x)d3x=‚à´dq‚Ä≤Œ¶(x‚Ä≤)d3x‚Ä≤.

2.3 Green‚Äôs Reciprocity Use

  1. In class, I partially did problem 1.13 of Jackson 3rd Edition (I only found the net charge on the upper of the plate). Find the net charge on the lower plate. Justify your steps at the level of detail given in class. (I stated an easy way of finding the net charge induced on the lower plate, but I want you to do it the long way, which requires steps similar to the ones used in class.)

  2. A point charge at a distance r from the origin is between two grounded spherical conducting shells of radius b and c that are centered on the origin. Find the net charge induced on the surfaces at b and c.

For discussion during the next class: In my solution to part 1., I used the continous form of reciprocity. Could I have solved it using the discrete form?

Solution

1. Let the unprimed system have a conducting plate in z=0 plane held at Œ¶=0 and a conducting plate in the z=d plane held at at Œ¶=Vo‚Äã.

Let the unprimed system have a conducting plate in the z=0 plane held at at Œ¶‚Ä≤=0, a conducting plate in the z=d plane held at Œ¶‚Ä≤=0, and a point charge q‚Ä≤ at (x,y,z)=(xo‚Äã,0,0).

One can use the equation from problem 1.11 of Jackson or start with

‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅ‚Ä≤Œ¶d3x=‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅŒ¶‚Ä≤d3x

and split the charge density into surface and volume charge densities œÉ and œÅv‚Äã, where the subscript v means charge not on the conducting surfaces S:

‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅv‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶d3x+‚à´S‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤Œ¶da=‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅv‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤d3x+‚à´S‚ÄãœÉŒ¶‚Ä≤da

The first term on RHS is zero because œÅv‚Äã=0 (there are no charges in the unprimed system between the plates). The second term on the RHS is zero becuase Œ¶‚Ä≤=0 on conducting surfaces.

The first term on the LHS reduces to q‚Ä≤Œ¶(xo‚Äã) becuase œÅv‚Ä≤‚Äã=q‚Ä≤Œ¥(x‚àíxo‚Äã)Œ¥(y)Œ¥(z) (the notation œÅv‚Ä≤‚Äã=q‚Ä≤Œ¥(x‚àíxo‚Äã‚Ä≤) is also acceptable; this gives Œ¶(xo‚Äã), which is the same things as Œ¶(xo‚Äã) notationally). The potential between the plates in the unprimed system is

Œ¶(x)=Vo‚Äãdx‚Äã

and so the first term on the LHS is q‚Ä≤Vo‚Äãxo‚Äã/d.

The second term on LHS is composed of integrals over the top and bottom surfaces (assuming all of the charges in the primed system are on the plates or at xo‚Äã; this is discussed below). Given that Œ¶=0 on bottom surface, we are left with an integral over upper surface (u) for which Œ¶=Vo‚Äã.

‚à´u‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤Vo‚Äãda=Vo‚Äã‚à´u‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤da=Vo‚Äãqu‚Ä≤‚Äã

The equation

‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅv‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶d3x+‚à´S‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤Œ¶da=‚à´allspace‚ÄãœÅv‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤d3x+‚à´S‚ÄãœÉŒ¶‚Ä≤da

thus reduces to

q‚Ä≤Vo‚Äãxo‚Äã/d+Vo‚Äãqu‚Ä≤‚Äã=0‚áíqu‚Ä≤‚Äã=‚àíqdxo‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

One can reverse the potentials on the unprimed system to arrive at the charge ql‚Ä≤‚Äã on the lower primed surface, which is

ql‚Ä≤‚Äã=q‚Ä≤(dxo‚Äã‚Äã‚àí1)‚Äã

Note also that the assumption that the total charge in the universe is zero

qu‚Ä≤‚Äã+ql‚Ä≤‚Äã+q=0

could have also been used to find ql‚Ä≤‚Äã given qu‚Ä≤‚Äã.

Note: In the solution, I assumed all free charges were on the upper and lower surfaces and there were no charges on far-away surfaces; this statement is justified post hoc by uniqueness and because computing qu‚Ä≤‚Äã and ql‚Ä≤‚Äã in this way gave qu‚Ä≤‚Äã+ql‚Ä≤‚Äã+q=0. To avoid this assumption, one would need to use equation 1.35 of Jackson with the volume being the volume between the plates. Curiously, in problem 1.11, Jackson suggests using equation 1.35 to come up with what he calls Green‚Äôs reciprocation theorem, seemingly so it could be applied in problem 1.12. However, the equation in problem 1.11 does not directly apply because the surface of the volume between the plates is not all conductor (only the top and bottom parts of the volume are conductors, the sides of this volume are not). One is left with having to use equation 1.35 and the argument that because the problem is 1-dimensional, the derivatives of the potential with respect to the normal on the side surfaces of the volume are zero.

2. The procedure here is nearly identical to part 1. The potential between the sphere in the unprimed system when the potential at r=b is Vo‚Äã and the potential at r=c is zero is

Œ¶(r)=Vo‚Äãc‚àíbb‚Äã(rc‚Äã‚àí1)

which can be found by solving the boundary value problem

Œ¶(c)=0Œ¶(b)=Vo‚Äã

‚àá2Œ¶=r21‚Äãdr2d2(r2Œ¶)‚Äã=0‚áíŒ¶=A+B/r

to find A and B or by assuming a charge Q on the outer sphere and ‚àíQ on the inner sphere and using Gauss‚Äô law to find Er‚Äã and then V(c)‚àíV(b)=‚àí‚à´bc‚ÄãEr‚Äãdr (the Q will cancel). The final result is

qr=b‚Ä≤‚Äã=‚àíVo‚Äãc‚àíbq‚Ä≤b‚Äã(ro‚Äãc‚Äã‚àí1)

qr=c‚Ä≤‚Äã=+Vo‚Äãc‚àíbq‚Ä≤c‚Äã(ro‚Äãb‚Äã‚àí1)

2.4 Green‚Äôs Identity Derivation

In one of the steps required to derive his identities (discussed in 1.8 of Jackson, 3rd Edition), Green said: ‚ÄúConsider the divergence of a scalar function f multiplied by a vector function A‚Äù.

  1. Show that

    ‚àá‚ãÖ(fA)=f‚àá‚ãÖA+A‚ãÖ(‚àáf)

    (this is equation 1.32 of Jackson)

  2. Show that

    ‚à´V‚Äãf‚àá‚ãÖAd3x=‚àí‚à´V‚ÄãA‚ãÖ(‚àáf)d3x+‚àÆS‚ÄãfA‚ãÖn^da

    where V is the volume enclosed by the surface S, n^ is the normal to a differential area element da on S, and d3x is a differential volume element. (This is needed in the following problem.)

  3. Verify the result in 2. by using an f, A and V of your choosing.

Solution

1. This can be shown by writing ‚àá and A in cartesian coordinates.

2. The divergence theorem

‚àÆS‚ÄãU‚ãÖda=‚à´V‚Äã‚àá‚ãÖUd3x

using U=fA on the LHS and U=f(‚àá‚ãÖA)+A‚ãÖ(‚àáf) the the RHS gives

‚àÆS‚ÄãfA‚ãÖda=‚à´V‚Äã[‚àá‚ãÖf(‚àá‚ãÖA)+A‚ãÖ(‚àáf)]d3x

and rearrangement gives

‚à´V‚Äãf(‚àá‚ãÖA)d3x=‚àí‚à´V‚ÄãA‚ãÖ(‚àáf)d3x+‚àÆS‚ÄãfA‚ãÖn^da

Note that when A=Ax‚Äã(x)x^, f=f(x), and V is a cube, this reduces to the integration by parts formula.

2.5 Alternative Derivation of Reciprocity for Continuous œÅ

Consider the integral

I=‚à´V‚ÄãE‚ãÖE‚Ä≤d3x

  1. Use E=‚àí‚àáŒ¶ and the result derived in the previous problem to re-write this equation in terms of a volume integral + a surface integral.

  2. Repeat 1. using E‚Ä≤=‚àí‚àáŒ¶‚Ä≤

  3. Show how the results from 1. and 2. can be used to show

‚à´all space‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤œÅd3x=‚à´all space‚ÄãŒ¶œÅ‚Ä≤d3x

which was a result derived in class last week using the discrete form of Green‚Äôs reciprocity theorem.

Solution

The identity from the previous problem is

‚à´V‚Äãf(‚àá‚ãÖA)d3x=‚àí‚à´V‚ÄãA‚ãÖ(‚àáf)d3x+‚àÆS‚ÄãfA‚ãÖn^da

or, switching locations of the volume integrals,

‚à´V‚ÄãA‚ãÖ(‚àáf)d3x=‚àí‚à´V‚Äãf(‚àá‚ãÖA)d3x+‚àÆS‚ÄãfA‚ãÖn^da

Using f=Œ¶‚Ä≤ and A=E in the identity and E‚Ä≤=‚àáŒ¶‚Ä≤ gives

I=‚à´V‚ÄãE‚ãÖ(‚àáŒ¶‚Ä≤)d3x=‚àí‚à´V‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤(‚àá‚ãÖE)d3x+‚àÆS‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤E‚ãÖn^da

Using f=Œ¶ and A=E‚Ä≤ in the identity and E=‚àáŒ¶ gives

I=‚à´V‚ÄãE‚Ä≤‚ãÖ(‚àáŒ¶)d3x=‚àí‚à´V‚ÄãŒ¶(‚àá‚ãÖE‚Ä≤)d3x+‚àÆS‚ÄãŒ¶E‚Ä≤‚ãÖn^da

(The two equations for I must be equal because the integrands on the left‚Äìhand side integrals are the same because E‚ãÖ‚àáŒ¶‚Ä≤=E‚ãÖE‚Ä≤=E‚Ä≤‚ãÖE=E‚Ä≤‚ãÖ‚àáŒ¶.)

Equating the two equations for I gives

‚àí‚à´V‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤(‚àá‚ãÖE)d3x+‚àÆS‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤E‚ãÖn^da=‚àí‚à´V‚ÄãŒ¶(‚àá‚ãÖE‚Ä≤)d3x+‚àÆS‚ÄãŒ¶E‚Ä≤‚ãÖn^da

If the volume is all space, the area of S becomes infinite. If all of the charges that make up œÅ and œÅ‚Ä≤ are confined to be in a sphere centered at the origin with a finite radius, then as the radius of S‚Üí‚àû, E‚Üír^/r2 and Œ¶‚Üí1/r and similar for E‚Ä≤ and Œ¶‚Ä≤. (You needed to provide some sort of justification similar to this in you solution - saying the potential and field approaches zero is not sufficient because the surface becomes infinite and you are left with ‚àû‚ãÖ0). So for S being a spherical surface with large r

‚àÆS‚ÄãŒ¶E‚Ä≤‚ãÖn^da‚âÉ‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0œÄ‚Äãr3QQ‚Ä≤‚Äãr2sinŒ∏dŒ∏dœï=4œÄrQQ‚Ä≤‚Äã

Where Q and Q‚Ä≤ are the total charges in the unprimed and primed system respectively. As a result of this argument, the surface integrals can be dropped and V can be replaced with all space and we are left with

‚à´all space‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤(‚àá‚ãÖE)d3x=‚à´all space‚ÄãŒ¶(‚àá‚ãÖE‚Ä≤)d3x

Finally, using ‚àá‚ãÖE=‚àí‚àá2Œ¶=œÅ/œµo‚Äã and ‚àá‚ãÖE‚Ä≤=‚àí‚àá2Œ¶‚Ä≤=œÅ‚Ä≤/œµo‚Äã gives

‚à´all space‚ÄãŒ¶‚Ä≤œÅd3x=‚à´all space‚ÄãŒ¶œÅ‚Ä≤d3x

1-D Cartesian Green Function

Two infinite and grounded conducting sheets are in the x=0 and x=w plane. In the x=x‚Ä≤ plane, there is an infinite non-conducting sheet with surface charge density œÉ‚Ä≤.

  1. Find the potential, œàl‚Äã(x), on the left (0‚â§x‚â§x‚Ä≤) and to the right (x‚Ä≤‚â§x‚â§w), œàr‚Äã(x), of the non-conducting sheet using any method (Gauss‚Äôs law or the boundary value method can be used; you should be able to do it using both methods, but you need to only show your work using one method).

  2. Write the potential œà(x) for 0‚â§x‚â§w as a single function using œàl‚Äã and œàr‚Äã and the Heavyside step function Œò. (In the future this œà (with œÉ‚Ä≤/œµo‚Äã set to 1), will be called a Green function, which is the motivation for the title of this problem.)

  3. Show that ‚àá2œà(x)=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤). You will need to use the fact that dŒò(x)/dx=Œ¥(x), and dŒò(‚àíx)/dx=‚àíŒ¥(x). Also compute ‚àá‚Ä≤2œà(x), where the prime means to take derivatives with respect to primed variables. (This may seem odd because x‚Ä≤ was defined to be a constant; here you are being asked to treat it as a variable. You should get an answer that is proportional to Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)).

As discussed in class, the motivation for solving this problem is that its potential, œà, can be used in Green‚Äôs second identity (eqation 1.35), which is a form of reciprocity, to solve the most general problem for this geometry. The most general problem is to find the potential Œ¶(x) when œÅ=œÅ(x) between x=a and x=b, the left plane is grounded, and the right plane is at potential Vo‚Äã. Instead of using œà found above to solve the most general problem, first use it to solve an easier problem:

  1. Use Equation 1.35 and œà(x) to find the potential Œ¶(x) when œÅ(x)=0 between the conductors and Œ¶(0)=0 and Œ¶(w)=Vo‚Äã. Include a sketch or a sentence where you define V and S when you use Equation 1.35. There will be a subtilty with notation here ‚Äì if you use Equation 1.35 as written, you‚Äôll end up with Œ¶(x‚Ä≤) and not the desired Œ¶(x).

Solution

1. One can answer this question by assuming a surface charge of œÉl‚Äã and œÉr‚Äã is induced on the plates at x=0 and x=w. Then use the formula œÉ/2œµo‚Äã for the electric field of the sheets of charge at œÉl‚Äã at x=0, œÉ‚Ä≤ at x=x‚Ä≤, and œÉr‚Äã at x=w to get the total field El‚Äã and Er‚Äã. The two unknowns, œÉl‚Äã and œÉr‚Äã, can be found by using the fact that the electric field in either of the conductors is zero - this yields œÉ‚Ä≤=‚àí(œÉl‚Äã+œÉr‚Äã), which is expected because the net charge in the universe is zero. The second equation needed to find œÉl‚Äã and œÉr‚Äã in terms of œÉ‚Ä≤ is

œà(w)‚àíœà(0)=0=‚àí‚à´0w‚ÄãEdx=‚àí‚à´0x‚Ä≤‚ÄãEl‚Äãdx‚àí‚à´x‚Ä≤w‚ÄãEr‚Äãdx

Alternatively, one can use the fact that ‚àá2œà(x)=0 has solutions of the form œà=A+Bx, the two boundary conditions and the continuity and jump conditions at x=x‚Ä≤.

œàl‚Äã=Al‚Äã+Bl‚Äãxœàr‚Äã=Ar‚Äã+Br‚Äãx

Boundary conditions:

œàl‚Äã(0)=0‚áíAl‚Äã=0

œàr‚Äã(w)=0=Ar‚Äã+Br‚Äãw‚áíAr‚Äã=‚àíBr‚Äãw

This leaves

œàl‚Äã=Bl‚Äãx and œàr‚Äã=Br‚Äã(x‚àíw)

Continuity:

œàl‚Äã(x‚Ä≤)=œàr‚Äã(x‚Ä≤)‚áíBl‚Äãx‚Ä≤=Br‚Äã(x‚Ä≤‚àíw)

Jump:

The jump condition follows from Gauss‚Äôs law with a Gaussian cylinder with one end cap to the left of x‚Ä≤ and the other to the right. It also follows from integrating ‚àá2œà=d(dœà/dx)/dx=‚àíœÉ‚Ä≤Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)/œµo‚Äã once with respect to x. The condition is

Er‚Äã‚àíEl‚Äã=œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã

or

[‚àí‚àÇx‚àÇœàr‚Äã‚Äã+‚àÇx‚àÇœàl‚Äã‚Äã]x=x‚Ä≤‚Äã=œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã

‚àíBr‚Äã+Bl‚Äã=œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã‚áíBl‚Äã=Br‚Äã+œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã

The three equations left are

Ar‚Äã=‚àíBr‚ÄãwBl‚Äãx‚Ä≤=Br‚Äã(x‚Ä≤‚àíw)Bl‚Äã=Br‚Äã+œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã

Solving gives

Bl‚Äã=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã(wx‚Ä≤‚Äã‚àí1) and Br‚Äã=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äãwx‚Ä≤‚Äã

So the final solution is

œàl‚Äã=œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã(1‚àíwx‚Ä≤‚Äã)xœàr‚Äã=œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã(1‚àíwx‚Äã)x‚Ä≤‚Äã

Note that swapping x and x‚Ä≤ in œàl‚Äã gives the equation for œàr‚Äã, and vice-versa. That is, œàl‚Äã(x‚Ä≤,x)=œàr‚Äã(x,x‚Ä≤).

2.

œà=œàl‚Äã(x)Œò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)+œàr‚Äã(x)Œò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)‚Äã

Checks:

  • When x<x‚Ä≤, Œò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)=1 and Œò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)=0, giving œà=œàl‚Äã.

  • When x>x‚Ä≤, Œò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)=0 and Œò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)=1, giving œà=œàr‚Äã.

3.

dxdœà‚Äã‚Äã=œàl‚Äã(x)dxd‚ÄãŒò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)+Œò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)dxdœàl‚Äã(x)‚Äã+œàr‚Äã(x)dxd‚ÄãŒò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)+Œò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)dxdœàr‚Äã(x)‚Äã‚Äã

If one plots œà(x), you will see that its derivative has a jump downwards at x=x‚Ä≤ of œÉ‚Ä≤/œµo‚Äã and so we expect the terms in dœà/dx with the derivative of the Heavyside step function, which is the delta function, to be zero. So the two terms involving derivatives of Œò will be addressed first.

The first term can be rewritten using

dxd‚ÄãŒò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)=‚àíŒ¥(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)=‚àíŒ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)

The first equality follows from the identity given in the problem statement: dŒò(‚àíx)/dx=‚àíŒ¥(x). The second equality is a standard delta function identity.

The second term is

dxd‚ÄãŒò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)=Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)

The following two equalities follow from the fact that Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤) is zero except at x=x‚Ä≤:

œàl‚Äã(x)Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)=œàl‚Äã(x‚Ä≤)Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)

œàr‚Äã(x)Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)=œàr‚Äã(x‚Ä≤)Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)

Given that œàr‚Äã(x‚Ä≤)=œàl‚Äã(x‚Ä≤), the two terms in dœà/dx involving derivatives of Œò cancel, leaving

dxdœà‚Äã=Œò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)dxdœàl‚Äã(x)‚Äã+Œò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)dxdœàr‚Äã(x)‚Äã

Straightforward calculation and use of the same identities as above gives

dx2d2œà‚Äã=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)

This matches expectations. For a sheet of charge in the x=x‚Ä≤ plane, the volume charge density is

œÅ=œÉ‚Ä≤Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)

and Poisson‚Äôs equation is ‚àá2œà=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÅ‚Äã

(Recall that the units of Œ¥(x) are inverse length. This follows from part of the definition of the delta function: ‚à´Œ¥(x)dx=1).

4. Equation 1.35 with œï replaced with Œ¶ is

‚à´V‚Äã(Œ¶‚àá2œà‚àíœà‚àá2Œ¶)d3x=‚àÆS‚Äã(Œ¶‚àÇn‚àÇœà‚Äã‚àíœà‚àÇn‚àÇŒ¶‚Äã)da

Let V be the volume spanned by x=[0,w], y=[0,b], and z=[0,b], where b is arbitrary. This volume has six surfaces and so the surface integral will have six parts.

In the volume integral, the term with ‚àá2Œ¶=0 because there is no charge in the volume of the Œ¶ system. Subtitution of ‚àá2œà=‚àí(œÉ‚Ä≤/œµo‚Äã)Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤) gives

(œÉ‚Ä≤/œµo‚Äã)‚à´V‚ÄãŒ¶Œ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)d3x=‚àÆS‚Äã(Œ¶‚àÇn‚àÇœà‚Äã‚àíœà‚àÇn‚àÇŒ¶‚Äã)da

Integration over x gives

‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶(x‚Ä≤)‚à´dydz=‚àÆS‚Äã(Œ¶‚àÇn‚àÇœà‚Äã‚àíœà‚àÇn‚àÇŒ¶‚Äã)da

Of the six sides of the surface, Œ¶=0 on all except the one in the x=w plane for which the outward normal is n=x. So

‚àÆS‚ÄãŒ¶‚àÇn‚àÇœà‚Äãda=‚à´Vo‚Äã[‚àÇx‚àÇœàr‚Äã‚Äã]x=w‚Äãdydz=Vo‚Äã‚à´[‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äãwx‚Ä≤‚Äã]dydz=‚àíVo‚Äãœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äãwx‚Ä≤‚Äã‚à´dydz

where œàr‚Äã=œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã(1‚àíwx‚Äã)x‚Ä≤ found in part 1. was used.

One could assert that we expect Œ¶ to depend only on x, so ‚àÇn‚àÇŒ¶‚Äã=0 on the other four faces, for which n=‚àíy,y,‚àíz,z. Alternatively, one can use symmetry make the same conclusion:

The sides of V that are in the x=0 and x=w plane have œà=0, so two of the surface integrals of ‚àÆœà‚àÇn‚àÇŒ¶‚Äãda are zero.

On the surface in the y=0 plane, n=‚àíy, so we need to evaluate

‚àí‚à´0w‚Äã‚à´0b‚ÄãŒ®(x,0,z)‚àÇz‚àÇŒ¶‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãy=0‚Äãdxdz

On the surface in the y=b plane, n=y, so we need to evaluate

‚à´0w‚Äã‚à´0b‚Äãœà(x,b,z)‚àÇz‚àÇŒ¶‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãy=b‚Äãdxdz

Because the geometry is invariant with respect to y, the two partial derivatives are equal and the sum of these two surface integrals is zero. An idential argument can be made for the surfaces at z=0 and z=b.

All of the parts of the volume and surface integrals have not been evaluated and so equation 1.35 reduces to

‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚ÄãŒ¶(x‚Ä≤)‚à´dydz=‚àíVo‚Äãœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äãwx‚Ä≤‚Äã‚à´dydz

or

Œ¶(x‚Ä≤)=Vo‚Äãwx‚Ä≤‚Äã

In the problem statement Œ¶(x) was requested. In the above equation, we have Œ¶ as a function of x‚Ä≤, which was a constant in the œà problem. Given that both x‚Ä≤ 0 and w, we can find any value of Œ¶ in this range by solving a problem with x‚Ä≤ set to that value. Thus, we can equivantly replace x‚Ä≤ with x and so we have shown

Œ¶(x)=Vo‚Äãwx‚Äã

1-D Spherical Green Function

Two conducting and grounded spherical shells of radius b and c are centered on the origin, and c>b.

A nonconducting spherical shell is centered on the origin and has a charge density of œÉ‚Ä≤ and radius r‚Ä≤, with b<r‚Ä≤<c.

  1. Find œài‚Äã(r), the potential between the inner conducting shell and the charged shell and œào‚Äã(r), the potential between the charged shell and the outer conducting shell. (Read the subscript i as ‚Äúinner‚Äù and o as ‚Äúouter‚Äù.)

  2. Find the surface charge densities on the inner and outer conductor.

  3. Verify that Gauss‚Äôs law is satisfied for a Gaussian sphere centered on the origin and with a radius that is between the charged shell and the outer conducting shell.

  4. Write the potential œà(r) for b‚â§r‚â§c as a single function using œài‚Äã and œào‚Äã and the Heavyside step function Œò.

Solution

1. Instead of starting with œài‚Äã=Ai‚Äã+Bi‚Äã/r and œào‚Äã=Ao‚Äã+Bo‚Äã/r, we immediately write

œài‚Äã=Ci‚Äã(r1‚Äã‚àíb1‚Äã) and œào‚Äã=Co‚Äã(r1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã)

because we know the potential must have a 1/r dependence and the above two equations satisfy œài‚Äã(b)=0 and œào‚Äã(c)=0. What is left then is to use the conditions œài‚Äã(r‚Ä≤)=œào‚Äã(r‚Ä≤) and Eo‚Äã(r‚Ä≤)‚àíEi‚Äã(r‚Ä≤)=œÉ‚Ä≤/œµo‚Äã to find the two unknows Ci‚Äã and Co‚Äã. The result is

œài‚Äã=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤2‚Äã(b1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã1‚Äã)(r‚Ä≤1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã)(r1‚Äã‚àíb1‚Äã)

œào‚Äã=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤r‚Ä≤2‚Äã(b1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã1‚Äã)(r‚Ä≤1‚Äã‚àíb1‚Äã)(r1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã)

Written in terms of the total charge q‚Ä≤ on the shell with charge density œÉ‚Ä≤ at r=r‚Ä≤, this is

œài‚Äã=‚àí4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Ä≤‚Äã(b1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã1‚Äã)(r‚Ä≤1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã)(r1‚Äã‚àíb1‚Äã)

œào‚Äã=‚àí4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Ä≤‚Äã(b1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã1‚Äã)(r‚Ä≤1‚Äã‚àíb1‚Äã)(r1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã)

As before, there is symmetry with respect to swapping the spatial coordinate r with a parameter r‚Ä≤: œài‚Äã(r,r‚Ä≤)=œào‚Äã(r‚Ä≤,r) (note that this is only after writing the potentials in terms of the charge on the shell at r=r‚Ä≤).

2. From Gauss‚Äôs law, near the surface of a conductor œÉ=‚àíœµo‚Äãdœà/dn, where n is in the direction perpendicular to the conductor and outwards. For the inner conductor, n=r; for the outer, n=‚àír. (Note that in Green‚Äôs second identity, the convention is that n is in the direction perpendicular to V and outwards.) Evaluation givves

œÉi‚Äã=‚àí4œÄq‚Ä≤‚Äã(b1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã1‚Äã)(r‚Ä≤1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã)[b21‚Äã]

œÉo‚Äã=+4œÄq‚Ä≤‚Äã(b1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã1‚Äã)(r‚Ä≤1‚Äã‚àíb1‚Äã)[c21‚Äã]

The charge induced on the inner and outer surface is

qi‚Äã=‚àíq‚Ä≤(b1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã1‚Äã)(r‚Ä≤1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã)

qo‚Äã=+q‚Ä≤(b1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã1‚Äã)(r‚Ä≤1‚Äã‚àíb1‚Äã)

Checks:

1. As r‚Ä≤‚Üíb, qi‚Äã‚Üí‚àíq‚Ä≤ and qo‚Äã‚Üí0.

2. As r‚Ä≤‚Üíc, qi‚Äã‚Üí0 and qo‚Äã‚Üí‚àíq‚Ä≤.

3. In HW #2.3.2, we found the charge induced when a point charge was at r‚Ä≤. We can use that answer and superposition to find the total charge induced if point charges are distributed uniformly on a sphere. This should match the total charge induced found in this problem. From #2.3.2, the answers were (with ro‚Äã replaced with r‚Ä≤):

qr=b‚Ä≤‚Äã=‚àíc‚àíbq‚Ä≤b‚Äã(r‚Ä≤c‚Äã‚àí1)=‚àíq‚Ä≤(b1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã1‚Äã)(r‚Ä≤1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã)

qr=c‚Ä≤‚Äã=+c‚àíbq‚Ä≤c‚Äã(ro‚Äãb‚Äã‚àí1)=+q‚Ä≤(b1‚Äã‚àíc1‚Äã1‚Äã)(r‚Ä≤1‚Äã‚àíb1‚Äã)

The ‚Äúsuperposition‚Äù argument requires a bit more justification. Consider two separate problems. In one problem there is dq‚Ä≤ at (r‚Ä≤,Œ∏‚Ä≤,œï‚Ä≤); call the potential for this single dq problem œà‚Ä≤(r,Œ∏,œï;r‚Ä≤,Œ∏‚Ä≤,œï‚Ä≤). This potential will satisfy

‚àá2œà‚Ä≤(r,Œ∏,œï;r‚Ä≤,Œ∏‚Ä≤,œï‚Ä≤)=‚àídq‚Ä≤Œ¥(r‚àír‚Ä≤) with œà‚Ä≤=0 at r=b and œà‚Ä≤=0 at r=c

In another problem, there is dq‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ at (r‚Ä≤,Œ∏‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,œï‚Ä≤‚Ä≤); call the potential for this single dq‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ problem œà(r,Œ∏,œï;r‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,Œ∏‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,œï‚Ä≤‚Ä≤). This potential will satisy

‚àá2œà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤(r,Œ∏,œï;r‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,Œ∏‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,œï‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)=‚àídq‚Ä≤Œ¥(r‚àír‚Ä≤‚Ä≤) with œà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤=0 at r=b and œà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤=0 at r=c

The sum œà‚Ä≤+œà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ satisfies

‚àá2(œà‚Ä≤+œà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)=‚àídq‚Ä≤Œ¥(r‚àír‚Ä≤)‚àídq‚Ä≤Œ¥(r‚àír‚Ä≤‚Ä≤) with œà‚Ä≤+œà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤=0 at r=b and œà‚Ä≤+œà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤=0 at r=c

This argument can be extended for an arbitrary number of differential charges on a sphere of radius r‚Ä≤.

We can conclude that the sum of the potentials for isolated charges at any position on a surface of radius r‚Ä≤ and r‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ satsifies Poisson‚Äôs equation and the boundary conditions, which is the same condictions that we require for the combined charge problem. The charge density obeys superposition: œÉ/epsilono‚Äã=‚àídœà/dn=‚àí(dœà‚Ä≤/dn+dœà‚Ä≤‚Ä≤/dn) so that the charge densities on the conductors for two charge case is the sum of the charge densities for from each individual case.

Another way of justifying superposition is to note that for the isolated dq‚Ä≤ problem, the net force on the charges induced on the conductors is zero. If dq‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ is introduced the net force on all of the induced charges will still be zero.

3.3 Jackson Equation 1.42

Before stating Equation 1.42, Jackson (3rd edition) notes that with Equation 1.35 and 1.39, it is simple to obtain a generalization of Equation 1.36.

Show the ‚Äúsimple‚Äù steps need to arrive at Equation 1.42.

Be very careful with notation. You‚Äôll need to think a bit about the justification and validity of swapping x and x‚Ä≤ and/or changing the dummy variable used in integration. When you do either of these, provide a justification so that I know you are not applying the ‚Äúanswer operator‚Äù.

Solution

In HW 3.1, the use of Green‚Äôs second identity resulted in a potential that depended on the primed variable because integration was performed over an unprimed area or volume. In that problem, an argument was given for why the prime variable could be simply replaced with the unprimed variable. In principle, one could always use the approach used in HW 3.1 to find Œ¶(x‚Ä≤) and then make an argument for why Œ¶(x) is the equation for Œ¶(x‚Ä≤) with the prime removed. In this problem, we follow Jackson‚Äôs logic for Equation 1.42 for which the result of integration is Œ¶(x), which depends on the unprimed variable.

Equation 1.35 is

‚à´V‚Äã(œï‚àá2œà‚àíœà‚àá2œï)d3x=‚àÆS‚Äã(œï‚àÇn‚àÇœà‚Äã‚àíœà‚àÇn‚àÇœï‚Äã)da

Using, œï=Œ¶(x), œà=G(x,x‚Ä≤), and ‚àá2Œ¶=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÅ‚Äã gives

‚à´V‚Äã(Œ¶(x)‚àá2G(x,x‚Ä≤)+G(x,x‚Ä≤)œµo‚ÄãœÅ(x)‚Äã)d3x=‚àÆS‚Äã(Œ¶(x)‚àÇn‚àÇG(x,x‚Ä≤)‚Äã‚àíG(x,x‚Ä≤)‚àÇn‚àÇŒ¶(x)‚Äã)da

We want the result after integration to depend on x, so change the integration variable to be primed. The derivatives must also be changed to be primed and G(x,x‚Ä≤) must be replaced with G(x‚Ä≤,x).

‚à´V‚Äã(Œ¶(x‚Ä≤)‚àá‚Ä≤2G(x‚Ä≤,x)+G(x‚Ä≤,x)œµo‚ÄãœÅ(x‚Ä≤)‚Äã)d3x‚Ä≤=‚àÆS‚Äã(Œ¶(x‚Ä≤)‚àÇn‚Ä≤‚àÇG(x‚Ä≤,x)‚Äã‚àíG(x‚Ä≤,x)‚àÇn‚Ä≤‚àÇŒ¶(x‚Ä≤)‚Äã)da‚Ä≤

Equation 1.39 is

‚àá‚Ä≤2G(x,x‚Ä≤)=‚àí4œÄŒ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)

where the prime means the partial derivatives are taken with respect to primed coordinates. In the above integral, we have ‚àá‚Ä≤2G(x‚Ä≤,x). For now, assume that ‚àá‚Ä≤2G(x‚Ä≤,x)=‚àá‚Ä≤2G(x,x‚Ä≤). The first then term evaluates to

‚à´V‚ÄãŒ¶(x‚Ä≤)(‚àí4œÄŒ¥(x‚àíx‚Ä≤))d3x‚Ä≤=‚àí4œÄŒ¶(x)

with this and rearrangement, we can write

Œ¶(x)=4œÄœµo‚Äã1‚Äã‚à´V‚ÄãG(x‚Ä≤,x)œÅ(x‚Ä≤)d3x‚Ä≤+4œÄ1‚Äã‚àÆS‚Äã(G(x‚Ä≤,x)‚àÇn‚Ä≤‚àÇŒ¶(x‚Ä≤)‚Äã‚àíŒ¶(x‚Ä≤)‚àÇn‚Ä≤‚àÇG(x‚Ä≤,x)‚Äã)da‚Ä≤

To get equation 1.42, one must justify

G(x,x‚Ä≤)=G(x‚Ä≤,x)

For a general function, say, g(x,y)=xy2, g(x,y)=xy2ÓÄ†=g(y,x)=yx2. Showing G(x,x‚Ä≤)=G(x‚Ä≤,x) in general is non-trivial and Jackson problem 1.14 gives a suggestion for the proof as does the second paragrapha of page 40. A footnote on page 40 gives a reference of the proof for 1.14(b). So ideally one would have cited the statement on page 40 of Jackson to justify the use of G(x,x‚Ä≤)=G(x‚Ä≤,x).

4.1 Green function for infinite dome

In class, I showed how to find the potential œà due to a point charge inside of a grounded, conducting, and closed dome when the radius of the dome is infinite. The potential was found using the method of images. (A dome is a hemisphere plus a cap.)

Use this œà and equation 1.35 of Jackson (or equation 1.42; œà is proportional to a Green function) to find the potential Œ¶ for the following problem:

An conducting dome has its base in the x‚àíy plane and the radius of the dome is infinite. There are no charges inside of the dome. The boundary of the dome is grounded except for the region between x2+y2<b, which is held at a potential of Vo‚Äã.

  1. Find the potential Œ¶(z) inside of the dome (the integral required to find Œ¶(x,y,z) requires an approximation of the integrand or numerical integration and will be considered in the future).

  2. Find the potential Œ¶(z) inside of the dome when b/z‚â™1. Do this by Taylor series expanding Œ¶(z) for small b/z. Does the answer make sense?

  3. Sketch the electric field lines inside of the dome.

Note that a related problem (but with a different Green function) considered in 2.6 of Jackson.

Solution

1. The potential that satisfies the boundary conditions in the limit that that that the radius of the dome is much larger than r‚Ä≤ is

œà=(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2+(z‚àíz‚Ä≤)2‚Äãkq‚Äã‚àí(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)2+(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)2+(z+z‚Ä≤)2‚Äãkq‚Äã

This equation was derived using the method of images in class and is the same equation that solves the problem for a point charge at x‚Ä≤ above an infinite grounded plane in the x-y plane. œà satisfies the boundary conditions that when z=0, œà(x,y,0)=0 and when r‚Ä≤‚â´r, œà=0 (showing the latter requires re‚Äìwriting the denominators in terms of r‚Ä≤ and r).

Given that we are only interested in the potential along the z‚Äìaxis, we can set x‚Ä≤=y‚Ä≤=0. (In 2.6 of Jackson, he does this after the integral required to find Œ¶(x,y,z) is found.) We then have

œà=x2+y2+(z‚àíz‚Ä≤)2‚Äãkq‚Äã‚àíx2+y2+(z+z‚Ä≤)2‚Äãkq‚Äã

Green‚Äôs second identity (Equation 1.35) with Œ¶ in place of œï is

‚à´V‚Äã(Œ¶‚àá2œà‚àíœà‚àá2Œ¶)d3x=‚àÆS‚Äã(Œ¶‚àÇn‚àÇœà‚Äã‚àíœà‚àÇn‚àÇŒ¶‚Äã)da

In this problem V is the volume of the dome and S has two surfaces ‚Äì a large disk in the x‚Äìy plane and the curved part of the dome.

The Laplacian of œà can be written down by inspection. The charge density is that for point charges at (x,y,z)=(0,y,¬±z‚Ä≤), so

‚àá2œà=‚àíœµo‚Äãq‚Äã[Œ¥(x)Œ¥(y)Œ¥(z‚àíz‚Ä≤)+Œ¥(x)Œ¥(y)Œ¥(z+z‚Ä≤)]

‚à´V‚ÄãŒ¶‚àá2œàd3x=‚àíœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚à´V‚ÄãŒ¶[Œ¥(x)Œ¥(y)Œ¥(z‚àíz‚Ä≤)+Œ¥(x)Œ¥(y)Œ¥(z+z‚Ä≤)]d3x

Œ¥(z+z‚Ä≤) is zero in V because z and z‚Ä≤ are positive in V. The integral simplifies to

‚à´V‚ÄãŒ¶‚àá2œàd3x=‚àíœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚à´V‚ÄãŒ¶Œ¥(x)Œ¥(y)Œ¥(z‚àíz‚Ä≤)d3x=‚àíœµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¶(0,0,z‚Ä≤)=œµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¶(z‚Ä≤).

Inside V, we were given that there are no charges, so ‚àá2Œ¶=0. Therefore, the left-hand side of Equation 1.35 reduces to ‚àí(q/œµo‚Äã)Œ¶(z‚Ä≤).

On S, œà=0, so the second surface integral is zero. We are left with

‚àíœµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¶(z‚Ä≤)=‚àÆS‚ÄãŒ¶‚àÇn‚àÇœà‚Äãda

The surface is composed of the two parts ‚Äì the curved part and its base. On the curved part, Œ¶=0 was given. On the base, Œ¶=0 for x2+y2<b2 and Œ¶=Vo‚Äã otherwise. As a result, the surface integral reduces to

‚àíœµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¶(z‚Ä≤)=‚à´x2+y2<b2‚ÄãVo‚Äã‚àÇn‚àÇœà‚Äãda.

In cylindrical coordinates, we have

‚àíœµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¶(z‚Ä≤)=Vo‚Äã‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0b‚Äã‚àÇn‚àÇœà‚Äãsdsdœï

The outward normal to V is -z, so

‚àíœµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¶(z‚Ä≤)=‚àíVo‚Äã‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0b‚Äã‚àÇz‚àÇœà‚Äãsdsdœï

What remains is to evaluate the partial derivative (and recall that ‚àÇœà/‚àÇz in the integral means ‚àÇœà/‚àÇz‚à£on S‚Äã). In this problem, ‚Äúon S‚Äù corresponds to z=0.)

‚àÇz‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=2kqs2+z‚Ä≤2‚Äã3z‚Ä≤‚Äã

Evaluation of the integral gives

‚àíœµo‚Äãq‚ÄãŒ¶(z‚Ä≤)=‚àí4œÄkqVo‚Äã[‚à£z‚Ä≤‚à£z‚Ä≤‚Äã‚àíb2+z‚Ä≤2‚Äãz‚Ä≤‚Äã]

Œ¶(z‚Ä≤)=Vo‚Äã[1‚àíb2+z‚Ä≤2‚Äãz‚Ä≤‚Äã]

Using the same arguments used in HW 3.1, we can replace z‚Ä≤ with z, leaving

Œ¶(z)=Vo‚Äã[1‚àíb2+z2‚Äãz‚Äã]

2. The solution can also be written (for z>0) as

Œ¶(z)=Vo‚Äã‚é£‚é°‚Äã1‚àí1+z2b2‚Äã‚Äã1‚Äã‚é¶‚é§‚Äã

Using the binomial expansion,

Œ¶(z)=Vo‚Äã[1‚àí(1‚àí21‚Äã(zb‚Äã)2+‚Ä¶)]

To lowest order in b/z,

Œ¶(z)‚âÉ2Vo‚Äã‚Äã(zb‚Äã)2z‚â´b

For large z, the (positive) charge on the disk appears as a point charge at the origin. As a result, we may expect that the potential will fall off as 1/z. Here the potential falls off more slowly. The reason is that there is also a contribution from the negative charges in the plane for s>b. As a result, for large z, the system appears to have zero charge at the origin and so there is no 1/z term. (The interpretation of the power series expansion of potential will be covered in more detail later.)

3. This was discussed in class. In general, it is easiest to draw equipotential lines starting with one near the boundary. Then, draw electric field lines that are perpendicular to the equipotential lines.

œàl‚Äã=‚àën=0‚àû‚ÄãAn‚Äãsin(nœÄy)sinh(nœÄx)

and

œàr‚Äã=‚àën=0‚àû‚ÄãBn‚Äãsin(nœÄy)sinh(nœÄ(x‚àí1))

satisfy ‚àÇ2œà/‚àÇ2x+‚àÇ2œà/‚àÇ2y=0 and the boundary conditions

œàl‚Äã(0,y)=0œàl‚Äã(x,0)=0œàl‚Äã(x,1)=0

œàr‚Äã(1,y)=0œàr‚Äã(x,0)=0œàr‚Äã(x,1)=0

The equations for œàl‚Äã and œàr‚Äã could have been derived using the above six boundary equations and starting with

œàl‚Äã=‚àën=0‚àû‚Äãsin(nœÄy)[An‚Äãsinh(nœÄx)+an‚Äãcosh(nœÄx)]

œàr‚Äã=‚àën=0‚àû‚Äãsin(nœÄy)[Bn‚Äãsinh(nœÄx)+bn‚Äãcosh(nœÄx)]

or most generally

œàl‚Äã=‚àën=0‚àû‚Äã[Anl‚Äãsin(nœÄy)+Bnl‚Äãcos(nœÄy)][Cnl‚Äãsinh(nœÄx)+Dnl‚Äãcosh(nœÄx)]

œàr‚Äã=‚àën=0‚àû‚Äã[Anr‚Äãsin(nœÄy)+Bnr‚Äãcos(nœÄy)][Cnr‚Äãsinh(nœÄx)+Dnr‚Äãcosh(nœÄx)]

However, the result will be the same. In problems such as these, it is often easier to reason out what the form of the solution will be rather than starting from the most general equation. In this case, we need the sin solution in the y direction because it can have zeros at two locations. The sinh(nœÄ(x‚àí1)) term is justified because we know that Asinhx and Bcoshx can be combined into a Csinh(x+Œ¥) with a ‚Äúphase‚Äù shift Œ¥.

The continuity condition

œàl‚Äã(x‚Ä≤,y)=œàr‚Äã(x‚Ä≤,y)

gives

‚àën=0‚àû‚ÄãAn‚Äãsin(nœÄy)sinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)=‚àën=0‚àû‚ÄãBn‚Äãsin(nœÄy)sinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))

It follows that

Bn‚Äã=sinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))sinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)‚ÄãAn‚Äã

The jump condition

[‚àí‚àÇx‚àÇœàr‚Äã‚Äã+‚àÇx‚àÇœàl‚Äã‚Äã]x=x‚Ä≤‚Äã=œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã

gives

n=0‚àë‚àû‚Äã(nœÄ)sin(nœÄy)[‚àíBn‚Äãcosh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))+An‚Äãcosh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)]=œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã

The term in square brackets

‚àíBn‚Äãcosh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))+An‚Äãcosh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)

rewritten using the continuity relationship Bn‚Äã=An‚Äãsinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)/sinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1)) is

An‚Äã[cosh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)‚àísinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))sinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)cosh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))‚Äã]

or

An‚Äãsinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))sinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))cosh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)‚àísinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)cosh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))]‚Äã

The numerator simplifies to sinh(‚àínœÄ)=‚àísinh(nœÄ). This can be seen by expanding the hyperbolic functions as exponentials or using the identity

sinh(Œ±‚àíŒ≤)=sinh(Œ±)cosh(Œ≤)‚àísinh(Œ≤)cosh(Œ±)

with Œ±=nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1) and Œ≤=nœÄx‚Ä≤.

The continuity condition equation thus simplifies to

n=1‚àë‚àû‚ÄãAn‚Äãsin(nœÄy)[sinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))nœÄsinh(nœÄ)‚Äã]=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã

Multiplication of this by sin(lœÄy)dy and integration from y=0 to 1 and using

‚à´01‚Äãsin(lœÄy)sin(nœÄy)dy=0 for lÓÄ†=n

‚à´01‚Äãsin(lœÄy)sin(nœÄy)dy=21‚Äã for l=n

‚à´01‚Äãsin(lœÄy)dy=lœÄ2‚Äã for l=1,3,5,‚Ä¶

gives (after changing the dummy index from l to n),

An‚Äã=‚àín2œÄ2œµo‚Äã4œÉ‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)sinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))‚Äã

Bn‚Äã=‚àín2œÄ2œµo‚Äã4œÉ‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)sinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)‚Äã

for n=1,3,5,‚Ä¶ and An‚Äã=Bl‚Äã=0 for n=2,4,‚Ä¶.

œàl‚Äã(x,x‚Ä≤)=‚àín=1,3,‚Ä¶‚àë‚àû‚Äãn2œÄ2œµo‚Äã4œÉ‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))sinh(nœÄx)sin(nœÄy)‚Äã

œàr‚Äã(x,x‚Ä≤)=‚àín=1,3,‚Ä¶‚àë‚àû‚Äãn2œÄ2œµo‚Äã4œÉ‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)sinh(nœÄ(x‚àí1))sin(nœÄy)‚Äã

or, using ‚àísinh(x)=sinh(x) and defining x<‚Äã to the the smaller of x and x‚Ä≤ and x>‚Äã to the the larger of x and x‚Ä≤,

œà(x,x‚Ä≤)=n=1,3,‚Ä¶‚àë‚àû‚Äãn2œÄ2œµo‚Äã4œÉ‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh(nœÄ(1‚àíx>‚Äã))sinh(nœÄx<‚Äã)sin(nœÄy)

or, in terms of Œò,

œà(x,x‚Ä≤)=œàl‚ÄãŒò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)+œàr‚ÄãŒò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)

2. Using G(x)=(4œÄœµo‚Äã/AœÉ‚Ä≤)œà(x) gives

G(x,x‚Ä≤)=AœÉ‚Ä≤4œÄœµo‚Äã‚Äã[œàl‚Äã(x,x‚Ä≤)Œò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)+œàr‚Äã(x,x‚Ä≤)Œò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)]

3. The surface integral in equation 1.44 of Jackson is zero (why?) leaving

Œ¶(x)=4œÄœµo‚Äã1‚Äã‚à´V‚ÄãG(x,x‚Ä≤)œÅ(x‚Ä≤)d3x‚Ä≤

G does not depend on y‚Ä≤ or z‚Ä≤ and œÅ=œÅo‚Äã=const, so integration over y and z gives

Œ¶(x)=4œÄœµo‚ÄãœÅo‚ÄãA‚Äã‚à´01‚ÄãG(x,x‚Ä≤)dx‚Ä≤

where A is as defined in the problem statement. Using G from part 2. gives

Œ¶(x)=œÉ‚Ä≤œÅo‚Äã‚Äã‚à´01‚Äã[œàl‚Äã(x,x‚Ä≤)Œò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)+œàr‚Äã(x,x‚Ä≤)Œò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤)]dx‚Ä≤

The step function modifies the limits of integration, so

Œ¶(x)=œÉ‚Ä≤œÅo‚Äã‚Äã‚à´x1‚Äãœàl‚Äã(x,x‚Ä≤)dx‚Ä≤+œÉ‚Ä≤œÅo‚Äã‚Äã‚à´0x‚Äãœàr‚Äã(x,x‚Ä≤)dx‚Ä≤

The interpretation of this equation is that to find the potential at x, sum over the potential due to differential sheets at different x‚Ä≤. The first integral is the potential just to the left of all differential sheets to the right of x. The second integral is the potential just to the right of all differential sheets to the left. This is the equation you would probably write down in order to compute the potential due to a slab if you did not know about Green functions ‚Äì the total potential is simply the sum of potentials due to all differential sheets.

The first integral requires the integration

‚à´x1‚Äãsinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))dx‚Ä≤=nœÄcosh(0)‚àícosh(nœÄ(x‚àí1))‚Äã

The second integral requires the integration

‚à´0x‚Äãsinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)dx‚Ä≤=nœÄcosh(nœÄx)‚àícosh(0)‚Äã

Using these, evaluation of the integrals gives

Œ¶(x)=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÄ34‚Äãn=1,3,5,‚Ä¶‚àë‚àû‚Äãn3sinh(nœÄ)sinh(nœÄy)‚Äã√ó

[sinh(nœÄx)(1‚àícosh[nœÄ(x‚àí1)])+sinh[nœÄ(x‚àí1)](cosh(nœÄx)‚àí1))]

Using again sinh(Œ±‚àíŒ≤)=sinh(Œ±)cosh(Œ≤)‚àísinh(Œ≤)cosh(Œ±)

with Œ±=nœÄ(x‚àí1) and Œ≤=nœÄ

Œ¶(x)=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÄ34‚Äãn=1,3,5,‚Ä¶‚àë‚àû‚Äãn3sinh(nœÄ)sinh(nœÄy)‚Äã[‚àísin(nœÄ)+sinh(nœÄx)+sinh[nœÄ(x‚àí1)]]

To combine sinh(nœÄx)+sinh[nœÄ(x‚àí1) into one term, note that when expanded in terms of exponentials the following sum has four terms

sinh(u)+sinh(u‚àí1)=21‚Äã(eu‚àíe‚àíu+eu‚àí1+e‚àí(u‚àí1))

The following product has four terms

coshŒ±sinhŒ≤=41‚Äã(eŒ±+Œ≤‚àíe‚àí(Œ±+Œ≤)+eŒ±‚àíŒ≤‚àíe‚àí(Œ±‚àíŒ≤))

Setting Œ±+Œ≤=u and Œ±‚àíŒ≤=u‚àí1

gives Œ±=u‚àí1/2 and Œ≤=1/2. Thus

sinh(nœÄx)+sinh[nœÄ(x‚àí1)]=2cosh[nœÄ(x‚àí1/2)]sinh(nœÄ/2)

and

sinh(nœÄ)‚àísin(nœÄ)+sinh(nœÄx)+sinh[nœÄ(x‚àí1)]‚Äã=[‚àí1+sinh(nœÄ)sinh(nœÄ/2)‚Äã2cosh[nœÄ(x‚àí1/2)]]

Finally, using

sin(2x)=2cosh(x)sinh(x)‚áísinh(x)=2cosh(x/2)sinh(x/2)

gives

sinh(x)sinh(x/2)‚Äã=2cosh(x/2)1‚Äã

and the final result of

Œ¶=œÄ3œµo‚Äã4‚Äãn=1,3,‚Ä¶‚àë‚àû‚Äãn3sin(nœÄy)‚Äã[1‚àícosh(nœÄ/2)cosh[nœÄ(x‚àí1/2)]‚Äã]

Defining m=(n‚àí1)/2 gives the result of problem 2.16 of Jackson.

2-D Cylindrical Boundary Value Problem

A non-conducting and infinitely long cylindrical shell of radius b has a surface charge density of œÉ=œÉ2‚Äãsin2œï.

  1. Find œà(s,œï) using the boundary value method. Note that the general solution to Laplace‚Äôs equation in cylindrical coordinates for a problem with no z dependence is

    œà=Ao‚Äã+‚àën=1‚àû‚Äã(An‚Äãcosnœï+Bn‚Äãsinnœï)sn+ao‚Äãlns+‚àën=1‚àû‚Äã(an‚Äãcosnœï+bn‚Äãsinnœï)s‚àín

  2. Repeat 1. assuming œÉ=œÉo‚Äã+œÉ2‚Äãsin2œï. In this case, the lns term cannot be dropped for the s>b solution; ao‚Äã is determined from the requirement that for large s, the potential should be that for a line of charge with linear density Œª that is the average of œÉ over œï.

Solution

I‚Äôll solve part 2., which reduces to part 1. if œÉo‚Äã=0. I will also solve this the long way. After solving this problem the long way, you should be able to identify short‚Äìcuts, one of which is find the potnential due to a long and uniformly charged cylinder and adding the result to the answer of part 1.

We can conclude that the sn terms are zero for the potential outside of the cylinder because at large s the cylinder will be approximately that for a line of charge, for which potential will be proportional to Œªlns for large s, where Œª is the azimuthally averaged surface charge density: Œª=‚à´02œÄ‚ÄãœÉbdœï. That is, for large s, the potential should be the same as that when all of the charge on the cylinder is collapsed onto a line, for which the potential is œà=const‚àí(Œª/2œÄœµo‚Äã)lns, giving ao‚Äã=‚àíŒª/2œÄœµo‚Äã and Ao‚Äã=const. The constant Ao‚Äã is determined by defining a reference potential Vr‚Äã at a reference point sr‚Äã. For example, if œà(sr‚Äã)=Vr‚Äã, then Vr‚Äã=Ao‚Äã‚àíŒªlnsr‚Äã/2œÄœµo‚Äã and the terms Ao‚Äã+ao‚Äãlns combine to form

Ao‚Äã+ao‚Äãlns=Vr‚Äã‚àí(Œª/2œÄœµo‚Äã)ln(s/sr‚Äã)

Note For a line of charge, we can‚Äôt choose a reference potential to be zero at infinity. This is related to the problem that arises if one attempts to use V=4œÄœµo‚Äã1‚Äã‚à´dq/‚à£r‚àír‚Ä≤‚à£ to compute the potential for an infinite line of charge. The derivation of this integral assumes that the potential is zero at large r. Using Gauss‚Äô law, one can show that this is not the case ‚Äì Es‚Äã=2œÄœµo‚ÄãŒª‚Äãs1‚Äã and so œà=œào‚Äã‚àí2œÄœµo‚ÄãŒª‚Äãlns, where œào is a constant. We can‚Äôt choose œà(s=‚àû)=0 because it gives œào‚Äã=‚àí‚àû. So to compute the potential for an infinite line of charge, one must either use the integral equation for the electric field or Gauss‚Äô law. See also 2.3.4 of Griffiths where he notes that the integral diverges for a charge distribution that extends to infinity.

Outside the cylinder, the general form is then

œào=Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã+ao‚Äãlns+‚àën=1‚àû‚Äã(an‚Äãcosnœï+bn‚Äãsinnœï)s‚àín

I‚Äôve kept the lns term. In the following, I‚Äôll show how the values of Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã and ao‚Äã given above follow from an alternative argument than the one given above.

Inside the cylinder, the potential should be finite and so the lns and s‚àín terms are dropped. (If the cylinder had a constant charge density, we would expect the potential to be constant inside of the cylinder and would keep only the Ao‚Äã term.)

Inside the cylinder, the general form is then

œài=Ao‚Äã+n=1‚àë‚àû‚Äã(An‚Äãcosnœï+Bn‚Äãsinnœï)sn

The two boundary conditions are

œào(b,œï)=œài(b,œï) and [‚àÇœào/‚àÇs‚àí‚àÇœài/‚àÇs]s=b‚Äã=‚àíœÉ/œµo‚Äã

(Make sure that you know how to derive the second boundary condition.)

The boundary condition œào(b,œï)=œài(b,œï) gives

Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã+ao‚Äãlnb+n=1‚àë‚àû‚Äã(an‚Äãcosnœï+bn‚Äãsinnœï)b‚àín=Ao‚Äã+n=1‚àë‚àû‚Äã(An‚Äãcosnœï+Bn‚Äãsinnœï)bn

This equation gives

Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã+ao‚Äãlnb=Ao‚Äã

and

An‚Äã=a‚àí2nan‚ÄãBn‚Äã=a‚àí2nbn‚Äãn‚â•1

from ‚Äúmatching terms‚Äù, which means integrating both sides by either cosn‚Ä≤œïdœï or sinn‚Ä≤œïdœï, with n‚Ä≤ being an integer greater than zero, and integrating from œï=0 to 2œÄ and using

‚à´02œÄ‚Äãcosndœï=0;‚à´02œÄ‚Äãsinndœï=0;‚à´02œÄ‚Äãcosn‚Ä≤œïsinnœïdœï=0

‚à´02œÄ‚Äãcosn‚Ä≤œïcosnœïdœï=0 if n‚Ä≤ÓÄ†=n and œÄ if n‚Ä≤=n

‚à´02œÄ‚Äãsinn‚Ä≤œïsinnœïdœï=0 if n‚Ä≤ÓÄ†=n and œÄ if n‚Ä≤=n

Notice that in cylindrical problems we integrate over œï, so the limits of integration are from 0 to 2œÄ. In contrast, in spherical problems with a Œ∏ dependence, we integrate from 0 to œÄ.

To determine the relationship between the coefficients quoted above, it is often easier to write out the first few terms in the sums

Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã+ao‚Äãlnb+‚àën=1‚àû‚Äã(an‚Äãcosnœï+bn‚Äãcosnœï)b‚àín=Ao‚Äã+‚àën=1‚àû‚Äã(An‚Äãcosnœï+Bn‚Äãcosnœï)bn

in alignment as

=‚Äã‚ÄãAo‚Ä≤‚Äã+ao‚ÄãlnbAo‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã++‚Äã‚Äã(a1‚Äãcosœï+b1‚Äãsinœï)b‚àí1(A1‚Äãcosœï+B1‚Äãsinœï)b1‚Äã‚Äã++‚Äã‚Äã(a2‚Äãcos2œï+b2‚Äãsin2œï)b‚àí2(A2‚Äãcos2œï+B2‚Äãsin2œï)b2‚Äã‚Äã++‚Äã‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

and then read off the matching terms

Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã+ao‚Äãlnb=Ao‚Äã

a1‚Äã/b=A1‚Äãbb1‚Äã/b=B1‚Äãb

a2‚Äã/b2=a2‚Äãb2b2‚Äã/b2=B2‚Äãb2

a3‚Äã/b3=a3‚Äãb2b3‚Äã/b3=B3‚Äãb2

‚Ä¶

in order to conclude the general result stated earlier of

Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã+ao‚Äãlnb=Ao‚Äã

An‚Äã=a‚àí2nan‚ÄãBn‚Äã=a‚àí2nbn‚Äãn‚â•1

The boundary condition

[‚àÇœào/‚àÇs‚àí‚àÇœài/‚àÇs]s=b‚Äã=‚àíœÉ/œµo‚Äã

gives

=‚Äã‚Äãao‚Äã/b‚àí(œÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)‚Äã‚Äã‚àí‚àí‚Äã‚Äã(a1‚Äãcosœï+b1‚Äãsinœï)b‚àí2(A1‚Äãcosœï+B1‚Äãsinœï)‚Äã‚Äã‚àí‚àí‚Äã‚Äã2(a2‚Äãcos2œï+b2‚Äãsin2œï)b‚àí32(A2‚Äãcos2œï+B2‚Äãsin2œï)b1‚àí(œÉ2‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)sin2œï‚Äã‚Äã++‚Äã‚Äã‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã

This gives

ao‚Äã/b=‚àíœÉ1‚Äã/œµo‚Äã

‚àía1‚Äã/b2‚àíA1‚Äã=0‚àíb1‚Äã/b2‚àíB1‚Äã=0

‚àí2a2‚Äã/b3‚àí2A2‚Äãb=0‚àí2b2‚Äã/b3‚àí2B2‚Äãb=‚àíœÉ2‚Äã/œµo‚Äã

‚àí3a3‚Äã/b4‚àí3A3‚Äãb2=0‚àí3b3‚Äã/b4‚àí3B3‚Äãb2=0

‚Ä¶

The equation ao‚Äã=‚àíbœÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã from the second boundary condition combines with Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã+ao‚Äãlnb=Ao‚Äã from the first boundary condition to give

Ao‚Äã=Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã‚àí(bœÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)lnb

The equation a1‚Äã/b=A1‚Äãb from the first boundary condition combines with ‚àía1‚Äã/b2‚àíA1‚Äã=0 from the second boundary condition to give

2A1‚Äã=0

which is only possible if A1‚Äã=0. Similarily, all terms except b2‚Äã and B2‚Äã are zero.

The equation b2‚Äã/b2=B2‚Äãb2 from the first boundary condition and ‚àí2b2‚Äã/b3‚àí2B2‚Äãb=‚àíœÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã combine to give

B2‚Äã=+œÉ2‚Äã/4bb2‚Äã=b3œÉ2‚Äã/4

The final result is

œài=Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã‚àí(bœÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)lnb+4œµ0‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äã‚Äãbs2‚Äãsin2œï

œào=Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã‚àí(bœÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)lns+4œµ0‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äã‚Äãs2b3‚Äãsin2œï

If the reference potential is chosen to be zero at s=0, then Ao‚Ä≤‚Äã=(bœÉ1‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)lnb and

œài=4œµ0‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äã‚Äãbs2‚Äãsin2œï‚Äã

œào=(bœÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)ln(b/s)+4œµ0‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äã‚Äãs2b3‚Äãsin2œï‚Äã

(In this problem, the reference potential was not given intentionally. Ideally you recognized that a reference potential was needed to fully specify the solution. Also note that we cannot specify a constant reference potential at any other s because the potential depends on œï.)

Note: Inspection of this answer suggests a faster way of solving the general problem of

œÉo‚Äã+œÉ1‚Äãsinœï+œÉ2‚Äãsin2œï+‚Ä¶

or more generally,

œÉo‚Äã+œÉ1s‚Äãsinœï+œÉ1c‚Äãcosœï+œÉ2s‚Äãsin2œï+œÉ2c‚Äãcos2œï+‚Ä¶

First find the potential due to œÉo‚Äã. Then, write œài and œào not as an infinite sum, but rather as a sum that involves only terms of sinnœï and cosnœï that appear in œÉ.

Check: Earlier it was argued that for large s, œào should approach

œào(s‚Üí‚àû,œï)‚Üíconst‚àí(Œª/2œÄœµo‚Äã)lns

where

Œª=‚à´02œÄ‚ÄãœÉbdœï

Using œÉ=œÉo‚Äã+œÉ2‚Äãsin2œï gives Œª=2œÄbœÉo‚Äã and so the computed value of œào of

œào=(bœÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)ln(b/s)+4œµ0‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äã‚Äãs2b3‚Äãsin2œï=(bœÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)lnb‚àí(bœÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)lns+4œµ0‚ÄãœÉ2‚Äã‚Äãs2b3‚Äãsin2œï

matches the limit

œào(s‚Üí‚àû,œï)‚Üíconst‚àí(Œª/2œÄœµo‚Äã)lns=const‚àí(bœÉo‚Äã/œµo‚Äã)lns
