6.1 Long Tube with Line of Charge

  1. Do problem HW problem 5.2.1 with the modification that œÉ‚Ä≤=Œª‚Ä≤Œ¥(y‚àíy‚Ä≤) and show that how it can be used to arrive at the result quoted in problem 2.15(b) of Jackson.

  2. Use your answer to part 1. and reciprocity to find the potential inside the tube when œÅ=0 inside the tube, the side at x=1 is held at a potential of Vo‚Äã, and the other three sides are grounded. (This is an analog to HW #3.1.4 where we solved a problem that was easy to solve without reciprocity using reciprocity).

Solution

1. The steps used to derive

Bn‚Äã=sinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))sinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)‚ÄãAn‚Äã

and

n=1‚àë‚àû‚ÄãAn‚Äãsin(nœÄy)[sinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))nœÄsinh(nœÄ)‚Äã]=‚àíœµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Ä≤‚Äã

were given in HW problem 5.2.1 and these equations are the starting point here.

For this problem, replace œÉ‚Ä≤ with œÉ‚Ä≤=Œª‚Ä≤Œ¥(y‚àíy‚Ä≤) in the above equation.

n=1‚àë‚àû‚ÄãAn‚Äãsin(nœÄy)[sinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))nœÄsinh(nœÄ)‚Äã]=‚àíœµo‚ÄãŒª‚Ä≤Œ¥(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)‚Äã

Multiplication of both sides by sin(lœÄy)dy and integration from y=0 to 1 and using

‚à´01‚Äãsin(lœÄy)sin(nœÄy)dy=0 for lÓÄ†=n

‚à´01‚Äãsin(lœÄy)sin(nœÄy)dy=21‚Äã for l=n

‚à´01‚Äãsin(lœÄy)Œ¥(y‚àíy‚Ä≤)dy=sin(lœÄy‚Ä≤)

gives, after changing the dummy index from l to n,

An‚Äã=‚àínœÄœµo‚Äã2Œª‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)sinh(nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1))‚Äãsin(nœÄy‚Ä≤)

Bn‚Äã=‚àínœÄœµo‚Äã2Œª‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)sinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)‚Äãsin(nœÄy‚Ä≤)

for n=1,2,3,‚Ä¶. Note that n is not constrained to be odd as it was in HW problem 5.2.1. The new result is

œàl‚Äã=‚àín=1‚àë‚àû‚ÄãnœÄœµo‚Äã2Œª‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh[nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1)]sinh(nœÄx)sin(nœÄy)sin(nœÄy‚Ä≤)

œàr‚Äã=‚àín=1‚àë‚àû‚ÄãnœÄœµo‚Äã2Œª‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh(nœÄx‚Ä≤)sinh[nœÄ(x‚àí1)]sin(nœÄy)sin(nœÄy‚Ä≤)

or, using ‚àísinh(x)=sinh(‚àíx) and defining x<‚Äã to the the smaller of x and x‚Ä≤ and x>‚Äã to the the larger of x and x‚Ä≤,

œà=n=1‚àë‚àû‚ÄãnœÄœµo‚Äã2Œª‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh[nœÄ(1‚àíx>‚Äã)]sinh(nœÄx<‚Äã)sin(nœÄy)sin(nœÄy‚Ä≤)

Using G=(4œÄœµo‚Äã/Lz‚ÄãŒª‚Ä≤)œà gives

G=8n=1‚àë‚àû‚Äãn1‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh[nœÄ(1‚àíx>‚Äã)]sinh(nœÄx<‚Äã)sin(nœÄy)sin(nœÄy‚Ä≤)

This is the same equation as problem 2.15 of Jackson except that the x and y variables are swapped. Given the fact that the problem is unchanged if the coordinates on the diagram for HW problem 5.2.1 are swapped, we are free to change replace x with y and vice-versa in our equation above and so we conclude that it follows from this geometrical symmetry that

G=8n=1‚àë‚àû‚Äãn1‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh[nœÄ(1‚àíy>‚Äã)]sinh(nœÄy<‚Äã)sin(nœÄx)sin(nœÄx‚Ä≤)

Alternatively, the equivalence can be proved using an identity such as equation 3.169 of Jackson.

2. First, obtain an answer using the standard boundary value method. The potential

Œ¶=n=1‚àë‚àû‚ÄãAn‚Äãsin(nœÄy)sinh(nœÄx)

satisfies the three boundary conditions for which the potential on the boundary is zero.

To determine An‚Äã, multiply both sides by sin(lœÄy)dy and integrate from y=0 to y=1. This gives

An‚Äã=nœÄ4Vo‚Äã‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãn=1,3,‚Ä¶andAn‚Äã=0n=2,4,‚Ä¶

and so the answer we expect is

Œ¶=n=1,3,‚Ä¶‚àë‚àû‚ÄãnœÄ4Vo‚Äã‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh(nœÄx)sin(nœÄy)

To solve this problem using G, we need to compute

Œ¶(x,y)=‚àí4œÄ1‚Äã‚àÆS‚ÄãŒ¶(x,x‚Ä≤,y,‚Ä≤y)‚àÇn‚Ä≤‚àÇG‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚ÄãS‚Äãda‚Ä≤

(You should be able to explain what happened to the other terms in 1.42 of Jackson, which the above is based on and also the justification for the following equation.)

For this problem, the required integration is

Œ¶(x,y)=‚àí4œÄ1‚Äã‚à´01‚Äã‚à´0Lz‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¶(x,x‚Ä≤=1,y,y‚Ä≤)‚àÇx‚Ä≤‚àÇG‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx‚Ä≤=1‚Äãdy‚Ä≤dz‚Ä≤

Using Œ¶(x,1,y,y‚Ä≤)=Vo‚Äã and the fact that integration over z‚Ä≤ gives Lz‚Äã, we have

Œ¶(x,y)=‚àí4œÄVo‚ÄãLz‚Äã‚Äã‚à´01‚Äã‚àÇx‚Ä≤‚àÇG‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx‚Ä≤=1‚Äãdy‚Ä≤

Using the relationship

G=Lz‚ÄãŒª‚Ä≤4œÄœµo‚Äã‚Äãœà

this is

Œ¶(x,y)=‚àí4œÄVo‚ÄãLz‚Äã‚ÄãLz‚ÄãŒª‚Ä≤4œÄœµo‚Äã‚Äã‚à´01‚Äã‚àÇx‚Ä≤‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx‚Ä≤=1‚Äãdy‚Ä≤

Using œà=œàl‚ÄãŒò(x‚Ä≤‚àíx)+œàr‚ÄãŒò(x‚àíx‚Ä≤),

‚àÇx‚Ä≤‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx‚Ä≤=1‚Äã=Œò(1‚àíx)‚àÇx‚Ä≤‚àÇœàl‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx‚Ä≤=1‚Äã+Œò(x‚àí1)‚àÇx‚Ä≤‚àÇœàr‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx‚Ä≤=1‚Äã

(The two other terms in ‚àÇœà/‚àÇx‚Ä≤ involving the derivative of Œò cancel; this was considered in a previous HW problem.) The second term in this equation is zero because the volume extends from x=0 to x=1 for which Œò(x‚àí1)=0. Also, in this range of x, Œò(1‚àíx)=1. This leaves

‚àÇx‚Ä≤‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx‚Ä≤=1‚Äã=‚àÇx‚Ä≤‚àÇœàl‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx‚Ä≤=1‚Äã

Using

œàl‚Äã=‚àín=1‚àë‚àû‚ÄãnœÄœµo‚Äã2Œª‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh[nœÄ(x‚Ä≤‚àí1)]sinh(nœÄx)sin(nœÄy)sin(nœÄy‚Ä≤)

gives

‚àÇx‚Ä≤‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx‚Ä≤=1‚Äã=‚àín=1‚àë‚àû‚Äãœµo‚Äã2Œª‚Ä≤‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãcosh(0)sinh(nœÄx)sin(nœÄy)sin(nœÄy‚Ä≤)

and the integral

Œ¶(x,y)=‚àí4œÄVo‚ÄãLz‚Äã‚ÄãLz‚ÄãŒª‚Ä≤4œÄœµo‚Äã‚Äã‚à´01‚Äã‚àÇx‚Ä≤‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx‚Ä≤=1‚Äãdy‚Ä≤

can be rewritten as

Œ¶(x,y)=n=1‚àë‚àû‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)2Vo‚Äã‚Äãsinh(nœÄx)sin(nœÄy)‚à´01‚Äãsin(nœÄy‚Ä≤)dy‚Ä≤

The integral is zero for n=2,4,‚Ä¶ and 2/nœÄ for n=1,3,‚Ä¶. The final result is then

Œ¶(x,y)=n=1,3,‚Ä¶‚àë‚àû‚ÄãnœÄ4Vo‚Äã‚Äãsinh(nœÄ)1‚Äãsinh(nœÄx)sin(nœÄy)

which is the same as the result found earlier.

6.2 Azimuthal Symmetry

1. Find Œ¶(r,Œ∏) for problem HW 4.1 in terms of an infinite sum involving the Legendre polynomials.

2. Find the surface charge density on the part of the dome in the x‚Äìy plane.

Notes

Try to work out œÉ using only the first few terms in the expansion. This will require only straightforward derivatives and the use of the table of Legendre polynomials.

Given that the exam is coming up, I‚Äôll make getting the general equation extra credit. As a hint, use the middle equation of 3.29 of Jackson, which is dPl+1‚Äã(u)/du=udPl‚Äã(u)/du+(l+1)Pl‚Äã(u) to compute the derivatives of the Legendre polynomial. Given that we are always evaluating at u=0 (corresponding to Œ∏=œÄ/2), you need to use dPl+1‚Äã(u)/du‚à£u=0‚Äã=(l+1)Pl‚Äã(0). This will give you a general equation for the derivative evaluated at u=0 ‚Ä¶ but you‚Äôll need to know Pl‚Äã(0). You can get that using the first equation of 3.29 of Jackson: (l+1)Pl+1‚Äã(u)‚àí(2l+1)uPl‚Äã(u)+lPl‚àí1‚Äã(u) with u=0. Extra extra credit if you plot the result.

Comments

Many students attempted to solve this using reciprocity. The potential œà for a point charge above a grounded plane can be written in terms of the Legendre polynomials (the terms will be proportional to [Pl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)‚àíPl‚Äã(‚àícosŒ∏)]/rl+1 ‚Ä¶ one could use the azimuthal symmetry trick to show this). To use reciprocity, one needs to evaluate

‚àÆŒ¶‚àáœà‚ãÖda

where Œ¶ is the desired potential. The surface is the entire dome, over which Œ¶ is zero except for s<b. As a result, one needs to integrate

‚à´02œÄ‚Äã‚à´0b‚ÄãVo‚Äã‚àÇz‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äãsdsdœï

It is possible to use this approach, but most students wrote down the wrong integral that needed to be evaluated.

Solution

1. Letting Vo‚Äã=1 so that potential is units of Vo‚Äã, the exact solution on the z‚Äìaxis is

Œ¶(z)=1‚àíb2+z2‚Äãz‚Äã

which can be written as

Œ¶(z)=1‚àí‚à£z‚à£z‚Äã1+z2b2‚Äã‚Äã1‚Äã

or

Œ¶(z)=1‚àí‚à£b‚à£z‚Äã1+b2z2‚Äã‚Äã1‚Äã

I‚Äôve kept the absolute values because in some problems, it matters. Here it does not because b is by definition positive, and we are considering the solution for z>0. We can thus write the exact solution as either

Œ¶o(z)=1‚àí1+z2b2‚Äã‚Äã1‚Äã

or

Œ¶i(z)=1‚àíbz‚Äã1+b2z2‚Äã‚Äã1‚Äã

Where the superscript indicates the equation will be used for either the outer ( o; z>b) or inner (i; z<b) solution.

The binomial expansion has the form

(1+Œ¥)n1‚Äã=1‚àínŒ¥+2!n(n+1)‚ÄãŒ¥2‚àí3!n(n+1)(n+2)‚ÄãŒ¥3‚Ä¶

For n=1/2, we have

(1+Œ¥)n1‚Äã=1‚àí21‚ÄãŒ¥+221‚Äã23‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥2‚àí3‚ãÖ221‚Äã23‚Äã25‚Äã‚ÄãŒ¥3‚Ä¶

Using Œ¥=b/z gives

(1+Œ¥)n1‚Äã=1‚àí21‚Äãz2b2‚Äã+221‚Äã23‚Äã‚Äãz4b4‚Äã‚àí3‚ãÖ221‚Äã23‚Äã25‚Äã‚Äãz6b6‚Äã‚Ä¶

Using this in the b/z expansion for Œ¶o gives

Œ¶o(z)=1‚àí1+z2b2‚Äã‚Äã1‚Äã=21‚Äãz2b2‚Äã‚àí221‚Äã23‚Äã‚Äãz4b4‚Äã+3‚ãÖ221‚Äã23‚Äã25‚Äã‚Äãz6b6‚Äã+‚Ä¶

or

Œ¶o(z)=l=2,4,‚Ä¶‚àë‚ÄãzlCl‚Äã‚Äã with Cl‚Äã=(‚àí1)(l/2+1)(l/2)!(l‚àí1)!!‚Äã2l/2bl‚Äã

where the double factorial is similar to the usual factorial with every other term omitted: n!!‚â°1‚ãÖ3‚ãÖ5‚ãÖ‚Ä¶n for n odd and n!!‚â°2‚ãÖ4‚ãÖ6‚ãÖ‚Ä¶n for n even.

We know that the potential for a charge distribution with azimuthal symmetry can be written in the form

œà(r,Œ∏)=l=0‚àë‚àû‚Äã(Al‚Äãrl+Bl‚Äãr‚àíl‚àí1)Pl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)

This equation must match a power series expansion of the potential along the +z-axis, which corresponds to Œ∏=0 and r=z.

œà(z)=l=0‚àë‚àû‚Äã(Al‚Äãzl+Bl‚Äãz‚àíl‚àí1)Pl‚Äã(1)

or, equivalently,

œà(z)=Ao‚ÄãP0‚Äã(1)+A1‚ÄãP1‚Äã(1)z+‚Ä¶+zBo‚ÄãP0‚Äã(1)‚Äã+z2B1‚ÄãP1‚Äã(1)‚Äã+‚Ä¶

The values of Pl‚Äã(1) can be determined from the first recursion relationship of 3.29 of Jackson:

(l+1)Pl+1‚Äã‚àí(2l+1)xPl‚Äã+lPl‚àí1‚Äã=0

with x=cos0=1, this is

(l+1)Pl+1‚Äã(1)=(2l+1)Pl‚Äã(1)‚àílPl‚àí1‚Äã(1)

The first few values can be computed manually

l=1P2‚Äã(1)=(3P1‚Äã(1)‚àíP0‚Äã(1))/2=1

l=2P3‚Äã(1)=(5P2‚Äã(1)‚àí2P1‚Äã(1))/3=1

l=3P4‚Äã(1)=(7P3‚Äã(1)‚àí3P2‚Äã(1))/4=1

Based on the above, we expect that Pl‚Äã(1)=1 for all l. (But this is not a proof.)

For this to match the z>b expansion

Œ¶o(z)=21‚Äãz2b2‚Äã‚àí221‚Äã23‚Äã‚Äãz4b4‚Äã+3‚ãÖ221‚Äã23‚Äã25‚Äã‚Äãz6b6‚Äã+‚Ä¶

we need Al‚Äã=0 for all l and

B0‚Äã=0 because there is no 1/z term in the z>b expansion.

B1‚Äã=+2b2‚Äã because the 1/z2 constants must match.

B2‚Äã=0 because there is no 1/z3 term in the z>b expansion.

B3‚Äã=‚àí221‚Äã23‚Äã‚Äãb4 because the 1/z4 constants must match.

B4‚Äã=0

B5‚Äã=+3‚ãÖ221‚Äã23‚Äã25‚Äã‚Äãb6

etc.

In summary,

B1‚Äã=+2b2‚ÄãB3‚Äã=‚àí221‚Äã23‚Äã‚Äãb4=‚àí83‚Äãb4B5‚Äã=+3‚ãÖ221‚Äã23‚Äã25‚Äã‚Äãb6=165‚Äãb6

and, with the Vo‚Äã recovered,

Vo‚Äãœà(r,Œ∏)‚Äã=21‚Äãr2b2‚ÄãP1‚Äã(cosŒ∏)‚àí83‚Äãr4b4‚ÄãP3‚Äã(cosŒ∏)+165‚Äãr6b6‚ÄãP5‚Äã(cosŒ∏)+‚Ä¶‚Äã

We can write the coefficients more generally. They are

Bl‚àí1‚Äã=Cl‚Äãl=2,4,‚Ä¶

That is,

Bl‚àí1‚Äã=(‚àí1)(l/2+1)(l/2)!(l‚àí1)!!‚Äã2l/2bl‚Äãl=2,4,‚Ä¶

Shifting the index by 1 gives

Bl‚Äã=(‚àí1)((l+1)/2+1)((l+1)/2)!l!!‚Äã2(l+1)/2bl+1‚Äãl=1,3,‚Ä¶

The above steps are what is needed to find the constants for the potential Œ¶o for z>b. The steps for finding the potential Œ¶i for z<b are similar. In this case, the Bl‚Äã terms are all zero and only every other Al‚Äã term is non‚Äìzero.

2. From 1., you will have a potential for z/b<1 of the form

œà(r,Œ∏)=r2B1‚ÄãP1‚Äã(cosŒ∏)‚Äã+r4B3‚ÄãP3‚Äã(cosŒ∏)‚Äã+‚Ä¶

From Gauss‚Äôs law, the surface charge density just outside of a conductor is œÉ=œµo‚ÄãE‚ãÖn^, where n^ is the outward normal to the surface. Equivalently,

œÉ=‚àíœµo‚Äã‚àÇn‚àÇœà‚Äã

where the partial derivative is evaluated at the the surface.

In this problem, n=z and we need to evaluate the partial derivative at z=0. That is, we need to compute

‚àÇz‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=[‚àÇz‚àÇ‚Äãr2B1‚ÄãP1‚Äã(cosŒ∏)‚Äã+‚àÇz‚àÇ‚Äãr4B3‚ÄãP3‚Äã(cosŒ∏)‚Äã+‚Ä¶]z=0‚Äã

Given that cosŒ∏=z/r, we can write

‚àÇz‚àÇœà‚Äã=[‚àÇz‚àÇ‚Äãr2B1‚ÄãP1‚Äã(z/r)‚Äã+‚àÇz‚àÇ‚Äãr4B3‚ÄãP3‚Äã(z/r)‚Äã+‚Ä¶]z=0‚Äã

To simplify notation, let

‚àÇz‚àÇœàl‚Äã‚Äã=‚àÇz‚àÇ‚Äãrl+1Bl‚ÄãPl‚Äã(z/r)‚Äã

so that

‚àÇz‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=[‚àÇz‚àÇœà1‚Äã‚Äã+‚àÇz‚àÇœà3‚Äã‚Äã+‚Ä¶]z=0‚Äã

For the first term, we have, using the product rule for derivatives

‚àÇz‚àÇœà1‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã‚Äã=‚àÇz‚àÇ‚Äãr2B1‚ÄãP1‚Äã(z/r)‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=[r2B1‚Äã‚Äã‚àÇz‚àÇ‚ÄãP1‚Äã(z/r)+B1‚ÄãP1‚Äã(z/r)‚àÇz‚àÇ(1/r2)‚Äã]z=0‚Äã=[r2B1‚Äã‚Äã‚àÇz‚àÇ‚ÄãP1‚Äã(z/r)]z=0‚Äã+B1‚ÄãP1‚Äã(0)‚àÇz‚àÇ(1/r2)‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã‚Äã

Given that P1‚Äã(0)=0, we are left with

‚àÇz‚àÇœà1‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=[r2B1‚Äã‚Äã‚àÇz‚àÇ‚ÄãP1‚Äã(z/r)]z=0‚Äã

At z=0, r=s (the radial cylindrical coordinate), so

‚àÇz‚àÇœà1‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=s2B1‚Äã‚Äã[‚àÇz‚àÇ‚ÄãP1‚Äã(z/r)]z=0‚Äã

Using the chain rule for derivatives

dudf(g(u))‚Äã=dgdf‚Äãdudg‚Äã

with f=P1‚Äã and g=z/r, the term in square braces can be re-written, giving

‚àÇz‚àÇœà1‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=s2B1‚Äã‚Äã[‚àÇg‚àÇP1‚Äã(g)‚Äã‚àÇz‚àÇ(z/r)‚Äã]z=0‚Äã

Using

‚àÇz‚àÇ(z/r)‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=[r1‚Äã‚àír2z‚Äã]z=0‚Äã=s1‚Äã

leaves

‚àÇz‚àÇœà1‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=s3B1‚Äã‚Äã‚àÇg‚àÇP1‚Äã(g)‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãg=0‚Äã

Repeating the above for ‚àÇœà3‚Äã/‚àÇz gives

‚àÇz‚àÇœà3‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=s5B3‚Äã‚Äã‚àÇg‚àÇP3‚Äã(g)‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãg=0‚Äã

In general,

‚àÇz‚àÇœàl‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=sl+2Bl‚Äã‚ÄãdgdPl‚Äã(g)‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãg=0‚Äã

Given that P1‚Äã(g)=g, ‚àÇg‚àÇP1‚Äã(g)‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãg=0‚Äã=1, and so

‚àÇz‚àÇœà1‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=s3B1‚Äã‚Äã

Given that P3‚Äã(g)=(5g3‚àí3g)/2, ‚àÇg‚àÇP3‚Äã(g)‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãg=0‚Äã=‚àí23‚Äã, and so

‚àÇz‚àÇœà3‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=‚àí23‚Äãs5B3‚Äã‚Äã

Given that P5‚Äã(g)=81‚Äã(63g5‚àí70g3+15g), ‚àÇg‚àÇP5‚Äã(g)‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãg=0‚Äã=815‚Äã, and so

‚àÇz‚àÇœà5‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=815‚Äãs7B5‚Äã‚Äã

To obtain a general solution, we need to know dPl‚Äã/dx‚à£x=0‚Äã. This can be found using the second equation of 3.29 of Jackson:

dxdPl+1‚Äã‚Äã‚àíxdxdPl+1‚Äã‚Äã‚àí(l+1)Pl‚Äã=0

When evaluated at x=0, this is

dxdPl+1‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=(l+1)Pl‚Äã(0)

Using again the first recursion relationship of 3.29 of Jackson

(l+1)Pl+1‚Äã‚àí(2l+1)xPl‚Äã+lPl‚àí1‚Äã=0

with x=0, gives

Pl+1‚Äã(0)=‚àíl+1l‚ÄãPl‚àí1‚Äã(0)

so

l=1, P2‚Äã(0)=‚àí21‚ÄãP0‚Äã(0)=‚àí21‚Äã

l=2, P3‚Äã(0)=‚àí32‚ÄãP1‚Äã(0)=0

l=3, P4‚Äã(0)=‚àí43‚ÄãP2‚Äã(0)=43‚Äã21‚Äã

l=4, P5‚Äã(0)=‚àí54‚ÄãP3‚Äã(0)=0

l=5, P6‚Äã(0)=‚àí65‚ÄãP4‚Äã(0)=‚àí65‚Äã43‚Äã21‚Äã

or, in general

Pl‚Äã(0)=l!!(l‚àí1)!!‚Äã(‚àí1)l/2l=2,4,‚Ä¶

From which it follows

dxdPl+1‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=0l=1,3,‚Ä¶

dxdPl+1‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=(l+1)l!!(l‚àí1)!!‚Äã(‚àí1)l/2=l!!(l+1)!!‚Äã(‚àí1)l/2l=2,4,‚Ä¶

Shifting the index by ‚àí1 gives

dxdPl‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=0l=0,2,‚Ä¶

dxdPl‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=(l‚àí1)!!l!!‚Äã(‚àí1)(l‚àí1)/2l=1,3,‚Ä¶

So the first few non‚Äìzero terms are

l=1dxdP1‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=0!!1!!‚Äã(‚àí1)0=1

l=3dxdP3‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=2!!3!!‚Äã(‚àí1)1=‚àí23‚Äã

l=5dxdP5‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=4!!5!!‚Äã(‚àí1)2=4‚ãÖ25‚ãÖ3‚ãÖ1‚Äã=815‚Äã

Check: Table 3.15 gives the first five Legendre polynomials. Manual evaluation of the derivatives gives:

dP0‚Äã(x)/dx=0

dP1‚Äã(x)/dx‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=1

dP2‚Äã(x)/dx‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=0

dP3‚Äã(x)/dx‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=‚àí23‚Äã

dP4‚Äã(x)/dx‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=0

From a table, P5‚Äã=81‚Äã(63x5‚àí70x3+15x) so

dP5‚Äã(x)/dx‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=815‚Äã

In summary,

œÉ=‚àíœµo‚Äã‚àÇz‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã

‚àÇz‚àÇœà‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=[‚àÇz‚àÇœà1‚Äã‚Äã+‚àÇz‚àÇœà3‚Äã‚Äã+‚Ä¶]z=0‚Äã

œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Äã=‚àís3B1‚Äã‚Äã+23‚Äãs5B3‚Äã‚Äã‚àí815‚Äãs5B5‚Äã‚Äã

With the Bl‚Äã values found earlier, this is

œµo‚ÄãœÉ‚Äã=‚àí21‚Äãs3b2‚Äã‚àí163‚Äãs5b4‚Äã‚àí128105‚Äãs7b6‚Äã

Recovering the Vo‚Äã and writing in non‚Äìdimensional form gives

Vo‚ÄãbœÉ/œµo‚Äã‚Äã=‚àí21‚Äãs3b3‚Äã‚àí83‚Äãs5b5‚Äã‚àí128105‚Äãs7b7‚Äã‚Äã

The leading order terms is negative as expected because the charge for z>b should be negative given that it is grounded and the inner circle is held at a positive potential.

The general equations found earlier are

‚àÇz‚àÇœàl‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=sl+2Bl‚Äã‚ÄãdxdPl‚Äã(x)‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã

where

Bl‚Äã=(‚àí1)((l+1)/2+1)((l+1)/2)!l!!‚Äã2(l+1)/2bl+1‚Äãl=1,3,‚Ä¶

and

dxdPl‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãx=0‚Äã=(l‚àí1)!!l!!‚Äã(‚àí1)(l‚àí1)/2l=1,3,‚Ä¶

The product of the last two equations is

(‚àí1)((l+1)/2+1)((l+1)/2)!l!!‚Äã2(l+1)/2bl+1‚Äã(l‚àí1)!!l!!‚Äã(‚àí1)(l‚àí1)/2

or

2(l+1)/21‚Äã((l+1)/2)!(l!!)2‚Äã(l‚àí1)!!1‚Äãbl+1l=1,3,‚Ä¶

so that

‚àÇz‚àÇœàl‚Äã‚Äã‚à£‚à£‚Äãz=0‚Äã=2(l+1)/21‚Äã((l+1)/2)!(l!!)2‚Äã(l‚àí1)!!1‚Äãsl+2bl+1‚Äã

and finally

Vo‚ÄãbœÉ/œµo‚Äã‚Äã=‚àíl=1,3,‚Ä¶‚àë‚àû‚Äã2(l+1)/21‚Äã((l+1)/2)!(l!!)2‚Äã(l‚àí1)!!1‚Äã(sb‚Äã)l+2

(To convert this to a sum over all positive integers, define l=2n+1.)

6.3 Sphere held at potential

In class, we started the problem of finding the potential inside and outside of a sphere of radius b that is centered on the origin and is held at potential V(b,Œ∏)=Vo‚Äãcos2Œ∏.

  1. Find Œ¶(r,Œ∏) (unless otherwise stated, this type of statement means for all r).

    Most students immediately re‚Äìwrote cos2Œ∏ as Vo‚Äã(Po‚Äã/3+2P2‚Äã/3) prior to starting to answer part 1. by using the fact that P2‚Äã=(3cos2Œ∏‚àí1)/2 and Po‚Äã=1. In the general case, it will not always be obvious how to express an arbitrary boundary potential V(Œ∏) in terms of the Legendre polynomials.

    In 3.2 of Jackson, he notes that an arbitrary function of Œ∏ (he uses x, which is also cosŒ∏) may be written as

    V(Œ∏)=l=0‚àë‚àû‚ÄãAl‚ÄãPl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)

    To find the coefficients Al‚Äã, multiply both sides by Pl‚Ä≤‚Äã(cosŒ∏)sinŒ∏dŒ∏ and then integrate from 0 to œÄ. (This is essentially what Griffiths calls ‚ÄúFourier‚Äôs trick‚Äù except using Legendre polynomials). By orthogonality, one then finds that

    Al‚Äã=22l+1‚Äã‚à´0œÄ‚ÄãV(Œ∏)Pl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)sinŒ∏dŒ∏

  2. Suppose V(b,Œ∏)=Vo‚Äã for Œ∏=0 to Œ∏=œÄ/2 and V(b,Œ∏)=‚àíVo‚Äã for Œ∏=œÄ/2 to œÄ. Write V(b,Œ∏) in the form A0‚ÄãP0‚Äã+A1‚ÄãP1‚Äã+A2‚ÄãP2‚Äã. That is, find a second‚Äìorder approximation to V(b,Œ∏) by finding A0‚Äã, A1‚Äã, and A2‚Äã. (If you use a formula from Jackson or elsewhere instead of doing integration to find A0‚Äã,A1‚Äã, and A2‚Äã, prove the formula.)

  3. Find Œ¶(r,Œ∏) using the boundary value V(b,Œ∏)=A0‚ÄãP0‚Äã+A1‚ÄãP1‚Äã+A2‚ÄãP2‚Äã.

  4. State at least one way that you can determine if your answer to part 3. makes sense.

  5. (Optional) Repeat this problem assuming that instead of being held at a potential, the sphere has a surface charge density of œÉ(b,Œ∏)=œÉo‚Äãcos2Œ∏ or œÉ(b,Œ∏)=œÉo‚Äã for Œ∏=0 to Œ∏=œÄ/2 and œÉ(b,Œ∏)=‚àíœÉo‚Äã for Œ∏=œÄ/2 to œÄ

Solution

1. By inspection of a table of Legendre Polynomials,

Vo‚Äãcos2Œ∏=Vo‚Äã[31‚ÄãP0‚Äã(cosŒ∏)+32‚ÄãP2‚Äã(cosŒ∏)]

The general solution to Laplace‚Äôs equation ‚àá2Œ¶(r,Œ∏)=0 is

Œ¶(r,Œ∏)=l=0‚àë‚àû‚Äã(Al‚Äãrl+Bl‚Äãr‚àíl‚àí1)Pl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)

As a result of holding the sphere at a potential, charges will build up on its surface. Far away from the surface, these surface charges will appear as a point charge. As a result, the potential should approach zero as r‚Üí‚àû, which requires Al‚Äã=0. We then are left with

Œ¶(r,Œ∏)=l=0‚àë‚àû‚ÄãBl‚Äãr‚àíl‚àí1Pl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)

Setting r=b, we have

Vo‚Äã[31‚ÄãP0‚Äã(cosŒ∏)+32‚ÄãP2‚Äã(cosŒ∏)]=l=0‚àë‚àû‚ÄãBl‚Äãb‚àíl‚àí1Pl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)

‚ÄúMatching terms‚Äù (meaning muliplying both sides by Pl‚Ä≤‚Äã(cosŒ∏)sinŒ∏ and integrating from Œ∏=0 to œÄ and using ‚à´‚àí11‚ÄãPl‚Ä≤‚Äã(x)Pl‚Äã(x)dx=2Œ¥l‚Ä≤l‚Äã/(2l+1)) gives

B0‚Äã=3Vo‚Äã‚ÄãB2‚Äã=32‚ÄãVo‚ÄãBl‚Äã=0 otherwise

Alternative (but conceptually the same) approach

In Griffiths example 3.7, the general solution for the potential outside of a sphere of radius b held at V(b,Œ∏) is given as:

Bl‚Äã=22l+1‚Äãbl+1‚à´0œÄ‚ÄãV(b,Œ∏)Pl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)sinŒ∏dŒ∏=22l+1‚Äãbl+1‚à´‚àí11‚ÄãV(b,x)Pl‚Äã(x)dx

where the last step used x=cosŒ∏. Plugging in the given boundary condition for V(b,Œ∏) gives

Bl‚Äã=Vo‚Äã22l+1‚Äãbl+1‚à´‚àí11‚Äã[31‚ÄãP0‚Äã(x)+32‚ÄãP2‚Äã(x)]Pl‚Äã(x)dx

For l=0,

B0‚Äã=Vo‚Äã2b‚Äã‚à´‚àí11‚Äã[31‚ÄãP0‚Äã(x)+32‚ÄãP2‚Äã(x)]P0‚Äã(x)dx

Using the orthogonality relationship

‚à´‚àí11‚ÄãPl‚Ä≤‚Äã(x)Pl‚Äã(x)dx=2l+12‚ÄãŒ¥l‚Ä≤l‚Äã

gives

B0‚Äã=Vo‚Äã3b‚Äã

For l=2,

B2‚Äã=Vo‚Äã25‚Äãb‚à´‚àí11‚Äã[31‚ÄãP0‚Äã(x)+32‚ÄãP2‚Äã(x)]P2‚Äã(x)dx

and the orthogonality relationship gives

B2‚Äã=32‚ÄãVo‚Äã

Œ¶(r,Œ∏)=Vo‚Äã[31‚Äãrb‚Äã+32‚Äã(rb‚Äã)3]

The 1/r term corresponds to the potential due to the net charge induced on the surface of the sphere. As a result, if we compute œÉ(b,Œ∏) and integrate over Œ∏, we expect to find the net charge q on the sphere is such that

kq=3Vo‚Äãb‚Äã

2. To find the coefficients Al‚Äã, multiply both sides by Pl‚Ä≤‚Äã(cosŒ∏)sinŒ∏dŒ∏ and then integrate from 0 to œÄ. (This is essentially what Griffiths calls ‚ÄúFourier‚Äôs trick‚Äù except using Legendre polynomials). By orthogonality, one then finds that

Al‚Äã=22l+1‚Äã‚à´0œÄ‚ÄãV(Œ∏)Pl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)sinŒ∏dŒ∏

Using x=cosŒ∏, this is

Al‚Äã=22l+1‚Äã‚à´‚àí11‚ÄãV(x)Pl‚Äã(x)dx

Using V(x)=Vo‚Äã for x>0 and V(x)=‚àíVo‚Äã for x<0 gives

Al‚Äã=22l+1‚Äã[‚àíVo‚Äã‚à´‚àí10‚ÄãPl‚Äã(x)dx+Vo‚Äã‚à´01‚ÄãPl‚Äã(x)dx]

Direct integration gives

A0‚Äã=0A1‚Äã=23‚ÄãVo‚ÄãA2‚Äã=0

Therefore, keeping only the first three terms of

V(Œ∏)=l=0‚àë‚àû‚ÄãAl‚ÄãPl‚Äã(cosŒ∏) gives V(Œ∏)=23‚ÄãVo‚ÄãcosŒ∏

This answer makes sense ‚Äì this potential is maximum at Œ∏=0, 0 at Œ∏=œÄ/2 and minimum at Œ∏=œÄ. This generally follows the pattern of the exact piecewise function that we are approximating.

(Equation 3.26 of Jackson gives a general equation for Al‚Äã, which can be derived using Legendre polynomial identities.)

3. Following steps similar to that used in part 1.

Œ¶(r,Œ∏)=Vo‚Äã23‚Äãr2b2‚ÄãcosŒ∏

4. Given that the net charge on the sphere is expected to be zero (the potential is symmetric about Œ∏=œÄ/2), we don‚Äôt expect a 1/r term. At r=b, Œ¶ matches the boundary condition V(b,Œ∏)=Vo‚ÄãcosŒ∏. This potential is also symmetric about Œ∏=œÄ/2, which is expected given the boundary condition has this symmetry.

An additional check that we can make is verify that the net charge is zero by computing œÉ and integrating it over Œ∏.

8.3 Point Charge and Dielectric Sphere

An origin‚Äìcentered dielectric sphere with radius b has a susceptibility of œáe‚Äã. A point charge is at (x,y,z)=(0,0,zo‚Äã), where zo‚Äã>b.

Find the potential. Note that as œáe‚Äã‚Üí‚àû, the solution should match that of a point charge outside of a conducting sphere.

Hints:

The potential will be due to the point charge and the bound charges induced on the sphere. You will need to consider three regions:

  1. r<b

  2. b<r<zo‚Äã

  3. r>zo‚Äã

In region 3., the potential due to the point charge can be expressed as (from 3.38 of Jackson)

œàq‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚à£x‚àíx‚Ä≤‚à£1‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äãl=0‚àë‚àû‚Äãrl+1zol‚Äã‚ÄãPl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)

In regions 1. and 2., the potential due to the point charge can be expressed as

œàq‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äã‚à£x‚àíx‚Ä≤‚à£1‚Äã=4œÄœµo‚Äãq‚Äãl=0‚àë‚àû‚Äãzol+1‚Äãrl‚ÄãPl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)

In all three regions, the contribution from the induced bound charges must have the form

œàb‚Äã(r,Œ∏)=l=0‚àë‚àû‚Äã(Al‚Äãrl+Bl‚Äãr‚àíl‚àí1)Pl‚Äã(cosŒ∏)

In region 1., the potential due to the bound charges will not have Bl‚Äã terms. In region 2. and 3., the potential due to the bound charges will not have Al‚Äã terms.
